title: tarberts senior citizens party the night away
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowWet and windy weather failed to dampen the spirits of Tarbert’s seniors as they gathered in the village hall for the senior citizens# Christmas dinner.A large number of willing volunteers had organised a sumptuous meal and decked the hall with multi-coloured fairy lights and balloons to provide a warm welcome for their guests.The familiar venue quickly came alive with smiles, hugs and the happy chatter of friends gathering for this much-loved annual event which has been going for more than  years.Elma McGougan and Jean Johnston, who had served on the original organising committee, reminisced about their experiences, explaining they ran fund-raising events and that many in the village donated money and goods so the dinner could be provided free of charge.The event, held this year on Friday January , is still organised by a committee and continues to be generously supported by businesses and iniduals in the village and surrounding area.Elma said: #In the s, the women on the committee made soup and brought it along. We did not have the new kitchen then. The hotel has always cooked the turkeys for us but cooking big pots of potatoes and vegetables was quite a job with just the gas rings. Back then, we had ice-cream and jelly for dessert.#Jean added: #It was all good fun and we had loads of laughs.#Elma continued: #We used to have sales to raise money for the dinner. Santa was on the stage and Jean’s children were his elves. They were only little then.#We modelled the clothes and the older women loved the bargains. We thought they were old, but they were probably the age we are now,# Elma said laughing. #We would shout #Roll up, roll up# to get them to come and see what we had on offer.#After a warm welcome from compère Martin Jefferies and a prayer of thanks for the food, the five-course meal was expertly served by members of the organising committee and their youthful helpers.A raffle, again free of charge, saw a large number of guests receive prizes and no-one was left disappointed as the remainder of the guests received selection boxes.Tarbert’s seniors showed they know how to party as dancers left their seats and enthusiastically took to the floor as soon as the musical entertainment began.A stunned Margaret Henderson was named #Citizen of the Year#, confessing she never expected to win the award.For more than  years, Margaret has collected money to support the Tarbert Sea Food Festival and Music Festival. Later, Margaret dressed up as Mrs Brown from Mrs Brown’s Boys to entertain the audience, something for which she is well-known.Martin Jefferies thanked everyone who had helped make the evening such a success with the happy gathering agreeing with loud applause.By Joan Crooks

title: marchmont-become-mecca-arts-crafts
story: A FORMER tech entrepreneur is driving a Borders mansion to the forefront of the new arts and crafts movement.The coming year will see a series of initiatives at Marchmont House near Greenlaw aimed at nurturing a st-century arts and crafts movement take place.The old stable block at the spectacular Borders mansion is being regenerated and transformed into workshops and studios for artists and makers.Marchmont will also be hosting a series of events that celebrate creativity, with themes including Arts and Crafts textiles and Pre-Raphaelite women mural artists.There will also be the unveiling of a new cycle of murals inspired by artists including Phoebe Anna Traquair in the Cupola Hall, which was redesigned by her friend the architect Sir Robert Lorimer.In a dferent vein a series of growing tree sculptures by the local artist Charles Poulsen will be completed and available to see during the summer.The projects are being driven by Marchmontrsquos director Hugo Burge.The former tech entrepreneur believes that the digital revolution needs to be balanced by a new movement promoting craftsmanship and human creativity that strengthen connections to the natural world.He said: ldquoAs someone whose career was built on the digital revolution I have a deep-seated love of technology and the incredible things it can achieve.ldquoBut it has limits and dangers that need to be countered by a st-century arts and crafts movement which takes from the past but looks to the future ndash a celebration of artists, skilled craft makers and designers, the beauty of nature and the importance of community.ldquoThis is what William Morris and others recognised as the Industrial Revolution, with its factories, mechanisation and global trade, was transforming their world.ldquoAnd itrsquos exactly what we need to do again today as digital technology transforms our own society and economy, often for the better but sometimes for the worse.Burge and his team have restored the palladian mansion, which was built in  but remodelled and enlarged by Lorimer between  and , and are turning it into a home for makers and creators.The plans for  include -Arts  Crafts Textiles celebration - nature, beauty and community from  to the present day on February . An in-depth look at Arts and Crafts textiles with a special focus on May Morris, daughter of William, and her contribution to the movement. There will also be a display of work by Naomi Robertson, Dovecot Master Weaver and head of studio, Louise Gardiner , Morag McPhersonand Barley Roscoe .Inspiring Women Artists - Legacies of Great Women Mural Painters  Artists of the Late th Century on April . A celebration of inspiring women mural painters and artists of the late th century, focusing on Phoebe Anna Traquair, Mary Seton Watts, Louisa Waterford and the women artists of the Pre-Raphaelite Sisterhood. This event will also see the unveiling of the Marchmont Mural Cycle a series of wall paintings by Julia Alexandra Mee inspired by the artwork of the Pre-Raphaelite artists and the Arts and Crafts Movement. Partners include The Royal Scottish Academy of Art  Architecture and the Womenrsquos Trust for Scotland.,params: .pushMarchmont Workshop  Makers Nest from April. Opening of new artists and craft makersrsquo workshops in the regenerated old stable block at Marchmont House.Reviving Heritage Crafts on August . A special event to mark the opening of a workshop for the making of traditional rush seated chairs. Marchmont sponsored apprentices Richard Platt and Sam Cooper to study in Warwickshire with Lawrence Neal, the last full-time professional maker of these beautul chairs. They are now going into business at Marchmont House. This event looks at what can be done to support the traditions of the past to help shape a more sustainable, hand crafted and beautul future.

title: rachael-hamilton-column
story: I hope everyone had a lovely Christmas and that  is a prosperous and happy year for everyone. We must spare a thought and thank all of those who worked tirelessly over Christmas from those serving in our armed forces, to the police and those who were caring for loved ones. We owe them a debt of gratitude and hope they got a chance to relax once the festivities were over.ScotRail woes continue into the New Yearmight be the year we finally see ScotRail sort out the mess on Scotlandrsquos railways. Scotlandrsquos train operator, Abellio, has posted losses for a third consecutive year. Prior to Christmas, I made it clear in Holyrood that delays and cancellations on the Borders Railway were unacceptable and I questioned the Scottish Governmentrsquos decision to terminate Abellio ScotRailrsquos contract early in .I believe the move will cause disruption to passengers and puts into question job security for current employees. Even Dominic Booth, Abellio UKrsquos managing director, said: lsquoScotlandrsquos railway needs stability, not the upheaval a change in the franchise would bring aboutrsquo. I completely agree, and I hope that investment in our railway isnrsquot halted as a result.More fuel to the fire came over Christmas, when it was revealed that Abellio ScotRail said it had ended the past financial year pound million in the red, owing pound million to its owner, the nationalised railway of the Netherlands. It now seems that Dutch taxpayers are subsidising our failing train services. This is on top of the Scottish Government subsidies, which make up about half of its pound billion revenues.We need a viable solution to ScotRailrsquos woes, and terminating franchises early or nationalisation is not the answer. We need better accountability and long-term planning to ensure we see the fortunes of ScotRail turn around.The Borders tourism can offer a more peaceful alternative to bustling CapitalI was not surprised to see that Edinburgh was revealed as having the fourth highest ratio of tourists to locals in the world. This is after Miami, Las Vegas and Dubai, and it sits well above th placed London. Statistics show there are nearly  tourists for every  residents in Edinburgh, and it begs the question, are we really managing the impact of tourism well Annually our Capital city is influxed with tourists for the Hogmanay celebrations and the Fringe. Whilst it great to see tourism booming in Edinburgh, we need to see more affirmative action to encourage tourists to see more of Scotland, including the Borders. We are located only an hour south of Edinburgh, yet we see very little of the footfall.We need to see incentives and drivers for visitors to explore outside of Edinburgh. Encouraging rural tourism is at the top of my list, and I believe the Scottish Government need to make it a priority to ensure that our overcrowded capital does not suffer, when rural areas have a more peaceful and less stressful visitor experience on offer.

title: polar-bear-expert-deliver-talk-galashiels
story: THE Arctic is ground-zero for climate change, and polar bears are on the front line.Yet, therersquos still a whole lot to learn about these magnicent animals. How many are there in the wild  And how will they respond to the dramatic loss of their icy home Whilst he hasnrsquot got all the answers to these questions, therersquos no doubt that WWF Chief Polar Advisor Rod Downie knows a thing or two about polar bears.Over the past few years, hersquos been one of only a handful of scientists to have undertaken direct scientic field research on these remarkable animals.Now hersquos sharing his understanding of ndash and encounters with ndash these icons on ice at a Royal Scottish GeographicalInspiring People talk in Galashiels on January .During his talk, Rod will examine the current status of polar bears, and future predictions linked to rapid Arctic warming.He will also explain the practical ins-and-outs of carrying out science in such an inhospitable location ndash and in extremely close proximity to such large natural predators.These include how scientists are able to take skin biopsies from big angry polar bears, how environmental DNA can be extracted from bear footprints, and how state-of-the-art airborne infrared photography is being used to census polar bear populations.Rod told us: "I will never forget the first time I came face-to-face with a large adult male polar bear in the wild. I look forward to sharing some of the exciting and innovative solutions that WWF have developed with our partners across the Arctic to help chart a future for these icons on ice.ldquoI feel very honoured and very humbled to be participating in the RSGS Inspiring People lecture series. Scotland is the Arcticrsquos closest neighbour."I grew up on the south west coast of Scotland and I have vivid childhood memories of , barnacle geese flying in from Arctic Svalbard and landing in the fields outside my house ndash Scotland and the Arctic are inherently linked.Rod will deliver his talk at the Heriot-Watt University Scottish Borders Campus on Tuesday, January  at .pm.Tickets for Rodrsquos talk - priced at pound and free for RSGS members, students and under s - will be available on the door or online via Eventbrite until noon the day before.Mike Robinson, chief executive of the RSGS, commented: ldquoIn spite of the threats posed to the arctic by global increases in temperature, Rod Downie and the WWF are working hard to promote a sustainable future for polar bears in the wild."I hope that these talks will inspire those in attendance to learn more about these incredible animals and encourage them to think more broadly about how we can preserve their habitat for generations to come.For more information see the RSGS website , RSGS social media, or contact the RSGS Communications Officer using the details supplied below.---ENDS---NOTES[] For more information on the RSGS http:www.rsgs.org[] Rod Downie is WWFrsquos Chief Advisor for Polar Regions. He grew up in Drummore on the Mull of Galloway, the southernmost village in Scotland. He has been working in the Polar Regions for two decades, initially at the British Antarctic Survey and for the last  years with WWF.

title: worldwide-recognition-galashiels-filmakers
story: GALASHIELS film-makers Roger Simian and Sarajane Swan are already in the frame for  after being selected for a world-wide tour.Their short film Alphonsos Jaw has been chosen for inclusion in the forthcoming TIME is Love tour.Started by African artist and curator, Kisito Assangni, as an annual video art program on the theme of love in hard times, the th edition of TIME is Love will be screened at arts venues and cinemas across the globe.Each year Assangni hand-picks artist-filmmakers from around the world to fill his programme.And to add icing to the cinematic cake for the Borders artists, the promotional tour poster features a still from Alphonsos Jaw.Sarajane and Roger, who work under the name Avant Kinema, developed their latest short film from a  installation at the Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival in Hawick.As well as the being included in the Time is Love tour, Roger and Sarajane have also been commissioned to create a multi-media artwork based on the final poem by the French Symbolist poet, Stephane Mallarme.The commission by New Modernist Editing Network will be part of the Imprints of the New Modernist Editing exhibition to be held in July at Shandy Hall near York.

title: new-poo-bag-dispensers-bins-installed-innerleithen
story: THE streets and green spaces of Innerleithen should soon be dog poo free thanks to a campaign by Innerleithen Community Council.Itrsquos a problem that blights towns and villages up and down the country, but there will soon be no excuses for foul play by dog owners with new bins with bag dispensers being located around the town.Following successful funding from the Localities Bid, bins have now been delivered and are ready to be installed.Community councillor Jackie Couchman updated members of the community council on progress with the project.The operation of removing the old bins and installing the new ones with dispensers, as well as the timetable for collecting waste and replenishing bags has been agreed with Scottish Borders Council.Locals are being encouraged to report anyone plundering dog poo bags and also dog walkers they witness not picking up after their pooch.A local resident said that dog fouling at the Strand had gotten worse over the last month and there reports of daily dog doo on Maxwell Street and DamsideMrs Couchman said: ldquoAt this time of year it always becomes worse under the cover of darkness but equally there are a lot of people that are diligent and do pick up.ldquoWersquove got to keep on top of it. Itrsquos one of those things that wonrsquot stay good so we must keep up the pressure on or it will slip.

title: sos-vets-expand-borders
story: AN emergency service for poorly pets in the Borders has expanded.The e-vets emergency service is now run seven nights a week and has transferred to bigger premises at Galedin Vets in Galashiels.Launched  months ago at Border Vets, which has branches in Galashiels, Selkirk and Innerleithen, e-vets initially provided a weekend out-of-hours service for the host practice and for Robert Young Vets in Kelso.The success of the service has seen it extended to seven nights a week with a team of three vets and four nurses, working on a rota basis from Galedin Vets at Easter Langlee Industrial Estate on Melrose Road in Galashiels.While e-vets currently serves Border Vets, Galedin Vets and Robert Young Vets, which are all part of the VetPartners group, it is hoped it will soon expand to offer out-of-hours care to other practices across the Borders.The team sees up to  cases a week and also provides over-the-phone advice.Typical cases from the last  months include a dog stung after disturbing a waspsrsquo nest, a dog eating socks, cats and dogs involved in road accidents and several poisoning cases.Lead vet Rosemary Webster told us: ldquoClients are really happy that calls come directly through to a vet or nurse and we can provide free advice. We have inpatients on site being monitored throughout the night and demand for the service is growing.ldquoAt first we were just doing weekends and now we are a seven-nights-a-week service because the demand is there. We hope to expand in  to offer out-of-hours care to other practices in the area.Pets are cared for overnight by Rosemary and her experienced emergency and critical care team, where they will receive the best possible care at Galedinrsquos surgery in Galashiels.Rosemary added: ldquoThe number one aim of the service is improving patient care because hospitalised pets will have -hour monitoring from vets and nurses, which is a big advantage and comfort to their owners.ldquoIn most situations animals are best treated at the clinic with access to all modern equipment. We can assist with transport concerns and do house visits when necessary.

title: selkirk-help-save-scotlands-red-squirrels
story: LAST week the County Hotel, Selkirk, played host for the second meeting of the newly named Selkirk and Ale Water Red Squirrel Network.The Red Squirrel Network will cover the land between Selkirk, Ashkirk, Ettrickbridge and Lilliesleaf.The new Selkirk and Ale Water group will join the other five south east Scotland groups as part of the Saving Scotlands Red Squirrels campaign to help improve the population of red squirrels in the Borders.The Scottish Borders Conservation Officer for Saving Scotlands Red Squirrels, Laura Preston, said to the group: "As soon as people see a red [squirrel], something just clicks."The Selkirk group will help plug the gap between the Tweeddale and Teviot groups where grey squirrels have continued to thrive.The second meeting welcomed in a dozen people who had an interest in red squirrel conservation, local wildle and some who hadpre-existing knowledge on grey squirrel control.During the meeting, Saving Scotlands Red Squirrels Community Engagement Officer, Sarah Cooper, explained what roles needed to be filled, what activities members could take part in, including fundraising, public events and the trapping and dispatching of grey squirrels.The group will be able to build up its own stock of grey squirrel traps, red squirrel feeders and event equipment using the pound start-up fund open to the Selkirk and Ale Water Network.Both Sarah and Laura then went on to explain how the group could access the resources available to them online, especially the page where squirrel sightings can be reported.If you were unable to make last weeks meeting, oryoure just a member of the public who wants to help out from home, the group has a tip which is handy to know,Laura told us: "The best thing that people can do is to report their squirrel sightings - so reds and greys."Laura added: "It helps us determine the presence and absence of red and grey squirrels and then that helps us determine where we are going to carry out our work."The next meeting of Selkirk and Ale Water Red Squirrel Network will be on Tuesday, February  at pm and is free to attend. The current location for this meeting isat the Lilliesleaf village hall .For more information about the Selkirk and Ale Water group, contact Sarah Cooper on scooper@scottishwildletrust.org.ukAnd to see what work is being done to help red squirrels, visit the Saving Scotlands Red Squirrels website at https:scottishsquirrels.org.uk

title: miranda-krestovnikoff-flies-film-festival
story: WELL known for her presenting work on programmes such as the BBCrsquos COAST and The One Show, Miranda Krestovnikoff has long had a passion for the natural world ndash particularly marine le.We caught up with Miranda ahead of her appearance at the Peebles Outdoor Film Festival later this monthWhat is it about the natural world that excites you so much Irsquove always been connected with wildle: as a child I used to spend all my spare time outside climbing trees or watching wildle. Therersquos always something new or remarkable to see.You are a keen er and have a particular love for waters close to home, including ScotlandYes, the waters around Scotland are rich in ersity and often the clarity is comparable to the Caribbean hellip just not quite as warm! Sometimes itrsquos the smaller creatures that are most fascinating.In Loch Carron on the Applecross peninsula, there are entire reefs created by small molluscs called flame shells. They form a thick mat which creates a stable surface for a vast array of organisms to set up home on, yet they remain hidden underneath. That is unless you peel away the edge of the mat which reveals crazy, orange-coloured creatures with long tentacles ndash a bit like Animal from the Muppet Show!Whatrsquos the most bizarre thing yoursquove had to do on TV One of the most unusual shoots was with a lady on Islay who would play her violin to the local grey seal population. As I am a flautist, I was askedI would play a duet with her hellipto the seals!We set out on a small boat to a group of rocks and sat there playing together. We roused quite an audience!You have a high-profile role with ious conservation charities, including serving as president of the RSPB. Tell us moreMany charitable organisations involve television personalities and presenters as a way of getting their message to a wide audience. As a communicator, I enjoy combining my passion for wildle on television with my involvement in conservation projects. I can help give these organisations a voice and really raise their profile on screen.What can audiences expect when you present in Peebles My talk will highlight some of the most memorable stories I have worked on as a wildle presenter ndash not least the challenges of filming underwater when the animals donrsquot really do what you want them to! It will be a behind-the-scenes trip through some of my best es, including being e-bombed by gannets, ing with a friendly dolphin and of course the wonderful grey seals of the Farne Islands. Itrsquos aimed at a wide audience, so families are very welcome!Miranda Krestovnikoff is one of the headline speakers at the  Peebles Outdoor Film Festival, held at the Eastgate Theatre, between January  and . Join her for The Sea Around Me, at pm on Friday, January  . Tickets available from Box Office on  , or online at www.eastgatearts

title: ghost-hunters-called-melrose-hotel-spooked-owners
story: PARANORMAL investigators are heading for Melrose.And they are inviting ghost hunters to join them for a night in one of the regions spookiest hotels.For decades staff and guests at the George and Abbotsford have reported eerie goings on.And its hoped that the professionals from UK and Scottish Ghost Nights will be able to get to the bottom of a few of the bumps in the night.Lisa Tedstill from UK and Scottish Ghost Nights told us: "We were invited to investigate the location by the new owners who reported many strange goings on."Staff have reported poltergeist activity, lights switching on by themselves and the poor chef even had her hair pulled so hard she fell backwards."We are quite surprised they have not all run away yet - and we are very excited to spend the night there."The historic George and Abbotsford dates back to the early s with extensions added towards the latter part of the th century.Members of the ghost-hunting team have already carried out a site visit.And they are convinced there are more spirits to be found than just those in the bottles.Lisa added: "On a site visit during the day, when the hotel was empty, we experienced a door handle rattling on its own, knocking on doors and a very disturbing growling sound coming from within one of the main bedroom corridors."We half expected a little boy on a trike to start trundling down the corridor.""The George and Abbotsford Hotel is a rabbit warren of a location, and it is the quintessential haunted hotel with years of history and ghost stories to tell."Tickets to take part in the ghost hunt on Saturday, March  from pm to am cost pound and are available from www.ukghostnightsFor the really brave there is also the opportunity to book an overnight room.

title: foundation-fishes-sponsors-ahead-salmon-trial
story: SCIENTISTS hoping to save the salmon industry on the Tweed are looking for sponsors to help fund a forthcoming study.Salmon numbers on the world-famous river are at their lowest since records began.In the space of less than a decade rod catches have gone from an all-time high of , to last years ,.And conservationists believe the loss of smolts on their way to the sea is a major factor.A survey carried out in  found that only  of the  transmitter-tagged smolts released in the Gala Water reached the North Sea.The pilot project was aimed at estimating survival rates, identying areas of high losses and establishing strategies to reduce the number of casualties.The Tweed Foundation want to now carry out a second study this spring - and they are seeking sponsors for each of the  tagged smolts to be released.A spokesman said: "With numbers of ing adult Salmon continuing to decline due to increasing marine mortality, we need to make sure as many smolts make it to the sea as possible by minimising losses as they pass down the river."It is only with hard evidence on the losses that take place and the causes of these losses that management can be improved and targeted to the best effect."The Tweed Foundation has been monitoring numbers of juvenile Salmon in the catchment since the early s."Despite the recent decline in numbers of adult fish, juvenile stocks have remained stable, mainly because it only takes a relatively small number of spawning fish to replenish the system."Smolts are therefore the weakest part of the in-river le cycle and where there is the greatest potential for management."As part of the forthcoming study anyone who sponsors a smolt will have access to regular updates on the progress of their fish via the foundations tracking blog.A single tag costs pound and the foundation is suggesting a minimum donation of pound.The spokesman added: "We will also be awarding a prize at the end of the smolt run for the fastest smolt to make it out of the estuary and into the sea, the start of their long migration to the feeding grounds."

title: galashiels-lizard-owner-faces-animal-ban
story: A GALASHIELS woman faces the possibility of a ban from being in charge of animals after admitting the neglect of a lizard in her care.Charlotte Roberts, , pleaded guilty to causing unnecessary suffering to the pet at her home in Beech Avenue between June  and September .She admitted failing to provide it with the appropriate care and treatment and not getting veterinary advice, leading to the lizard suffering from health conditions including emaciation and dehydration.A not guilty plea from her partner Vickie Roberts, , also of Beech Avenue, to a similar charge was accepted by the Crown.Depute fiscal Fiona Hamilton explained that a complaint was made to the Scottish SPCA about animal neglect at the property.She said: "Officers arrived on October  and found a  week old puppy and a large number of cats,  in all."Charlotte said she had a Bosc monitor lizard which in her words was in a very bad condition."It was motionless and in a state of collapse. It had no water. The water dish was dry and was full of wood shavings."She explained that the vets in Galashiels would not see her animals as she had outstanding bills to pay."Ms Hamilton said Charlottes partner ed to the property and they were told that all the dogs and cats in the property needed to be treated for fleas.She added that the Scottish SPCA immediately removed the lizard for veterinary attention.The lizard was found to be very weak and emaciated. Its weight was . kilogrammes when it should be a healthy weight of between .kilogrammes and three kilogrammes.The lizard had seven days of treatment which proved to be successful as it was fed back to le.It has now being signed over to the Scottish SPCA.Defence lawyer Mark Harrower admitted his client had been out her depth when it came to looking after the lizard.He said: "Her partner got it for her on Facebook and she had it for a few months."It said they could not get advice or vets treatment because of an outstanding bill.Mr Harrower continued: "I would put this down to inexperience and not knowing how to look after it rather than deliberate neglect.He pointed out it was only the lizard that had been taken away from the property.But the Crown also raised a motion for a disqualication order against Roberts from being in charge of animals.At that point it was decided Roberts should appear personally and sentence was deferred at Selkirk Sherf Court until February .Sherf Raymond McMenamin said: "It is a disturbing situation."

title: plans-welcomed-new-cctv-cameras-selkirk
story: COMMUNITY leaders are focussing on installing new CCTV to the streets of Selkirk.A recent report by Scottish Borders Council revealed that one-in-four of their cameras across eight towns in the region dont work.And the majority of the others are out of date and needing replaced.But a stand-off between the local authority and Police Scotland over who should fund a replacement system has led to doubts over the future of the cameras.Business leaders in Selkirk have now priced up a new system for their own town centre.And a communications company has already carried out a study to provide costings.Up to six of the latest remote-controlled -degree cameras would be installed along the High Street, in West Port, at the War Memorial and also aimed at the Fleshmarket Steps.Selkirkshire councillor Caroline Penman said: "We are looking to get the CCTV up and running as soon as possible."These would be -degree rotational cameras with analytics which will be used by the police."A plan is in place as well as costings so it is now up to the community to seethere is enough support."The project is being led by officials at the Selkirk Business Improvement Districtcompany, Selkirk Means Business.And they will conduct a consultation over the coming weeks to gauge opinion.Councillor Penman added: "There have been issues in the past where robberies have gone unsolved because the CCTV footage wasnt good enough."This would also deter things like anti-social behaviour."The new CCTV would make Selkirk a safer place to live and work."The proposed system, which would be part funded by Selkirk Means Business as well as grants from the local authority, would provide four-weeks of backdated recording at any time for investigating officers, as well as remote access to view live footage from the cameras.The planned CCTV has been welcomed by Selkirk Community Council.Chairman Alistair Pattullo said: "This has to be a good thing for the town."Taking the viewing screens out of the police station would make the system more accessible and effective."

title: invited-follow-borders-ballet-stars-shoes
story: A BUDDING ballet star from Melrose is urging fellow dancers from the Borders to pull on their tutus and tights for an upcoming audition.Sophie McGarry, who recently turned , has already caught the eye of mentor Peter Schaufuss.The Olivier Award-winning dance legend has recently established the world-class training academy, Edinburgh Festival Ballet School ,in the capitalrsquos New Town.And he is hoping that the region will deliver more bright prospects.Sophie is already relishing the opportunity to be a part of the school - a role she fits around her studies at Earlston High School.Auditions take place on Saturdayfor a limited number of coveted places to study from September.The former Parkside and Melrose Primary pupil told us: "To anyone who is keen to learn in ballet, Irsquod say lsquogo for itrsquo."Itrsquos a really amazing experience, and I feel like Irsquove grown a lot."You have to be very committed to attend weekend classes for hours, but Edinburgh Festival Ballet School has helped me improve a lot in the last few months."They give you room to build your style of dancing and to show your personality."My main tutor is school principal Johan Christensen and Irsquove been taught by Peter Schaufuss himself a few times, which was a big privilege."Irsquod love to carry on at the part-time school for a couple of years, and it would be pretty cool to be part of a Peter Schaufuss full-time school after that."Peter Schaufuss famously founded the English National Ballet in  and has, in a stellar career, performed and directed all over the world.He hopes the upcoming auditions will unveil more talented dancers to follow in Sophies ballet shoes.Peter said: ldquoEdinburgh Festival Ballet School provides a place where some of the finest young performers in Scotland can go to obtain a professional full-time dance education while living and training in Edinburgh."I wanted to pass on what I have learnt through all my years of experience in the dance world and we have been delighted with the success of the pilot course run in the past year."Irsquove been heartened to witness first-hand the progress of our full-time cohort and younger part-time dancers.ldquoWe are auditioning for places on our full-time school and our part-time school so there are opportunities for both experienced students who are already on the way to making a career as a dancer, as well as those who have raw talent and the desire to succeed but only basic experience of ballet.There will be  places up for grabs during Saturdays auditions.Open to youngsters aged  and over, to book a place for Saturday email administrator Lee Walls at lee@rosetheatreedinburgh

title: naval-seaman-admits-innerleithen-racism
story: A -year-old man has admitted making racial comments during an incident with police in Innerleithen.David Williams pleaded guilty to making offensive and racial remarks in High Street and in a police vehicle en-route to Hawick Police Station on October .Selkirk Sherf Court was told that police officers on mobile patrol noticed a group of men arguing outside the Unionist Club.They spoke to Wiiliams of Clarkston, Glasgow, who became aggressive and accused police of not showing him respect as he was in the Royal Navy.He then made comments about how the police should be concentrating on arresting "Pakis" and "terrorists."His lawyer said that a criminal conviction for this type of offence could affect his Royal Navy career and askedan admonition could be imposed.Sherf Raymond McMenamin said he would defer sentence for three months for good behaviour and the matter would be look at again when it recalls on April .

title: bonnie-babies-winner
story: AFTER weeks of voting across the Borders, we can now reveal the winner of rsquos Bonnie Babies competition.For the second year running Salva Duncan from Peebles has scooped the prize.The Borderand the Peeblesshire News received hundreds of votes in a bid to take the pound cash prize.Salva, who is now almost two years old, was entered this year by her dad Ronnie after previously being put forward by mum Cheryl in last yearrsquos competition.Cheryl was surprised to hear about her daughter being entered and winning the competition for a second year, as she hadnrsquot realised Salvarsquos dad had put their daughter forward.She said: ldquoI did not know he was entering her again, I was happy that she won last year but clearly proud dad had dferent ideas.ldquoAlthough he wanted to get through the first round, I think momentum got the better of him and here we are with a second win which Irsquom shocked by as I had no involvement this time.Both parents are very pleased that their daughter has done so well in this yearrsquos competition.Ronnie told us: ldquoWe are really, really surprised that Salva won again.ldquoI canrsquot thank my colleagues at the Stable Bar and also at the Horseshoe enough for voting for her.ldquoIrsquom sure it was their votes that made the dference.Cheryl joked: ldquoI was happy she won the first time, Irsquom delighted shersquos won the second time but there will be no third time.ldquoThank you to anyone who voted and we will be making a donation, this time to a childrenrsquos charity.

title: innerleithen-makes-herstory-knockout-drag-weekend
story: LAST Saturday night in Innerleithen definitely was nota drag.Brought to Innerleithen Memorial Hall by On the Brinck Promotions and Hemelvaart Bier Cafeacute, the Drag Race Showcase event on Saturday, January  was a smash-hit with fans of Drag and the cult-classic TV series Rupauls Drag Race.The Borders event saw two of the top stars from the UK version of the American Drag series take to the stage, performing as iniduals and as a duo, even performing a Pete Burns number together.Baga Chipz and The Vivienne, who won the first series of Rupauls Drag Race UK in November last year, not only served looks, but also held a meet and greet at the show.Phil Walker from Hemelvaart told us: "It was amazing! Really brilliant show."It exceeded all of our expectations and we canrsquot wait for the next one."Next month Drag Race royalty willto Innerleithen.The second place winner of the UK series, Divina De Campo will bring her one-of-a-kind act, and her four and a half octave vocal range to the Memorial Hall on Saturday, February .Phil added: "We are really excited about our second RuPaulrsquos Drag Race UK Scottish Borders Party with Divina De Campo next month."We have seen Divina perform already, last November in Ayton and she absolutely brought the house down."She is the most genuine person you could hope to meet, extremely funny and insanely talented. She has been perfecting her craft for years and is a true star in every sense."On Drag Race UK she said that she could sing a four and a half octave range in five dferent languages whilst doing the splits. People should come along,for no other reason, just to seethat is true."And Lourde Godd willto the stage too - Hemelvaarts regular Drag host will also perform as well as taking up her role of introducing the other performers on the night.The audience will also be treated to a special live performance from Scottish X Factor  finalist, Emily Middlemas, who has released new music under the name ili.Food and drink on the night wont be a problem either as a bar and street food vendors will be at hand to cater for hungry guests.For a sickening night, tickets for the VIP meet and greet for Divina De Campos night in Innerleithen are limited, and are selling fast.Standing tickets for the night cost pound and the VIP tickets are pound.To purchase tickets, visit https:on-the-brinck.square.site The Drag Race Showcase event is open to over s, but any person under the age of  must be accompanied by an adult.Read our last Drag Race Showcase article here.

title: 45-year-old-admits-causing-primary-school-disturbance
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered into a Newtown St Boswells woman who admitted being involved in a disturbance at a local primary school.Jillian Reid, , of Glenburn Avenue, pleaded guilty at Selkirk Sherf Court to behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by shouting and swearing, making threatening and abusive remarks and pushing another person on the body.The offence happened at Newtown Primary School on September .Sentence was deferred until February  for the production of a Criminal Justice Social Work Report.

title: three-way-negotiations-begin-crumbling-selkirk-wall
story: SELKIRK could be set for another traffic stand-off following concerns over a crumbling wall in the town.A forced one-way system operated for more than four years during a dispute over a roadside wall in Yarrow Terrace.A resolution for rebuilding the wall was only reached in  between a hotelier and the local authority.But similar negotiations have now begun with three dferent landowners over a deteriorating wall along Dunsdale Road.Selkirkshire councillor Gordon Edgar said: ldquoThe condition of wall is being discussed by our officers and it is a matter for negotiations.ldquoThere are three dferent properties along the stretch of road.Issues with standing water and the crumbling wall have regularly been raised at meetings of Selkirk Community Council over the past couple of years.Despite attempts to clean out drains, the issue of pooling water has continued.Councillor Edgar added: ldquoOfficers have examined the drainage again recently to see why the water isnrsquot draining away.ldquoWe are awaiting the results of their tests before anything can be done.

title: grahame-calls-council-fix-borders-roads
story: A LOCAL MSP has called on Scottish Borders Council to prioritise the quality of roads in the region.Christine Grahame MSP raised concerns after seeing the state of the tarmac on the roads connecting the Borders alongside faded white lines and missing cats eyes.Ms Grahame said: "I regularly drive many of these roads whilst working in my constituency and very much share the concerns of my constituents about their safety."Particularly in Winter when the dark draws in, a lack of proper white lining, hidden potholes and missing cats eyes can make driving much more dficult, indeed Irsquom alarmed to hear stories of near misses on these roads as a result."The council has a duty to make sure the roads are made safe for those who rely on them - it must prioritise their maintenance to bring them back to an acceptable standard and to avoid future accidents."If the council can find money to speculatively buy the Lowood Estate for pound million for a risky property development scheme, it should be able to find money to make the roads useable ndash priorities have to sht at SBC."As previously reported, the poor condition of the B from Heriot to Innerleithen and the A from Peebles towards Eddleston have seen members of the public call on their community councils to help fix dangerous pot-holes.This includes three members of the same family having their cars damaged by pot-holes on the A within weeks of one another.SBC councillor Gordon Edgar, executive member for roads and infrastructure,at a recent meeting of Selkirk Community Council, said: "Our recent budget consultation showed that the service believed to require the most attention and money was roads."

title: selkirk-tv-thief-ordered-good-behaviour
story: A SELKIRK man who walked out of a Galashiels store with a television has been ordered to be of good behaviour for the next six months.Paul Crow of Buccleuch Road, pleaded guilty to the theft which happened at Asda in Currie Road, Galashiels, on August .Fiona Hamilton, prosecuting, told Selkirk Sherf Court that a member of staff had noticed the -year-old walking out of the store with the television valued at pound.He was confronted in the car park and the police were called.There was full recovery of the television set.Sherf Raymond McMenamin told Crow he was giving him a chance by deferring sentence for good behaviour until June  but warned him of the repercussions of there was any further offending.

title: 20-year-old-admits-string-offences-galashiels
story: BACKGROUND reports have been ordered into a Galashiels man who admitted a total of three offences at Selkirk Sherf Court.Twenty year old Louis Heatlie pleaded guilty to assaulting a male to his injury in Gala Park on October  by repeatedly punching him to the head and body.He also admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner near his Glendinning Terrace home on November  by damaging a car windscreen with a pumpkin, adopting an aggressive attitude towards two named people and kicking a number of bins and a vehicle, as well as spitting on a police officer.Sherf Kevin Duffy said that in view of the nature of the offences he would be calling for a Criminal Justice Social Work Report and a Restriction of Liberty Order assessment.

title: primark-open-18-new-stores-year
story: Primark plans to open  new stores this year as they continue their expansion programme.The retail giant has reported higher revenues on the back of new store openings, as UK like-for-like sales dipped marginally lower.The high street fashion chains growth helped drive revenues up at owner Associated British Foods , which saw group revenues rise % over the -week period to January .Primark saw its UK sales grow by % as it benefited from new stores and expansions, while sales across the retailer were up %.The company hailed "good trading" over November and December, despite highlighting a "marginal decline" in like-for-like sales.Meanwhile, ABF said Primark saw sales in its Eurozone business jump .% higher on the back of "strong progress in France and Italy".Primark said it heavily benefited from three store openings during the period, as well as site expansions.It said it expects to open  new stores during the financial year as it continues its expansion programme.Elsewhere, ABF was bolstered by its strengthening sugar business, which saw revenues increase % after EU sugar prices remained higher than over the same period last year.It said lower costs in sugar production also mean that there will be a material improvement in profits from the sugar arm, particularly in the second half.ABF said grocery sales were level against the same period last year, although profit margins improved.Increased popularity of herbal teas in the UK and US helped to improve revenues at its Twinings ision, while efficiencies in the tea supply chain also helped to improve profits.ABF said operating losses at its troubled Allied Bakeries business, which makes Kingsmill bread, were reduced after "progress from cost reduction" more than offset lower sales.

title: parents-school-staff-back-week-holiday-february
story: COUNCILLORS are expected to rubber-stamp plans for introducing a new weeks holiday in February for pupils across the Borders.But the changes may only last for two years, as talks are taking place about bringing the region into line with neighbouring education areas.Schools in the Scottish Borders currently close for two days in the middle of the month with an additional in-service day also taking place.Following a recent public consultation on holidays and in-service days, which attracted more than , responses, a full February week is the favoured option for future years.As well as the five-day closure in February, which includes an in-service day, the preferred option will include two days of in-service training for teachers at the end of the main summer holidays in August instead of one.And an additional in-service day will also be added onto the end of the October week.But the two current in-service days at the start of November will be scrapped.The changes are expected to to be implemented for   and  , but future years will depend on discussions taking place about alignment with the local authority areas of Midlothian, East Lothian, Fe and Edinburgh.Carolyn Didcock from Scottish Borders Council said: "There was a total of , responses to the consultation and the preferred option is two in-service days after the summer break, one in-service day after the October break, one in-service day in February with the schools closed for one week in February for pupils and four days for staff."There will also be one in-service day in May - the Tuesday after the May bank holiday."However, discussions are about to commence to consider aligning in-service days and holidays for other local authorities."In light of the above, it is proposed that the school holidays and in-service dates for   and   are published on the councilrsquos website."In the interim, the preferred holidays and in-service days for the academic years  ,   and   are held pending the discussions with the other local authorities."Staff, parents and other members of the public voted by  to  for implementing the proposed changes.Members of the ruling administration at Scottish Borders Council will discuss the findings at their meeting on Tuesday.

title: peebles-set-jump-front-replacement-school-queue
story: PEEBLES is set to get a new school following the fire that destroyed a large part of the building last year.The replacement secondary, though, will take at least three years to build.But according to Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Chief Executive Tracey Logan, it is the only way forward for Peebles High.Although it is yet to be officially endorsed by the local authority, Ms Logan says her view is that apart from the Sports Complex and Millennium Wing, the entire school will be demolished and rebuilt.And that Peebles High will jump to the head of the queue in the rebuilding programme of schools - ahead of Galashiels, Hawick and Selkirk.But the Chief Executive told the towns Community Council she thinks Peebles should now be first on the priority list for a new school.Ms Logan explained: ldquoAt the moment my view is, and this is only my view, this has not even endorsed by the Council as yet, is that given the constraints that we have around what will be available financially, the Scottish Government have been really helpful in that they are offering their full support and we will make a bid late spring for funding through the schools programme.ldquoThere will obviously be a financial settlement from the insurance."But we need to find the best way forward, so my expectation is that we will retain the Sports Complex because it is undamaged and pretty new, we will also retain the Millennium Wing because again itrsquos not that old and is entirely usable.ldquoI would imagine that we will probably end up taking away everything  and replace it with something new."What that will look like, I have no idea. But what it will be is something that is modular that we can add ontowe need to for capacity and we will want to talk to the community about what  we might want to put into that site.A consultation will take place asking for local feedback on community space and the possible provision of health and social care.She added: ldquoSome people have said to me that they want to knock all of the school down including the fairly new bits, realistically that wonrsquot happen and itrsquos not the right thing to do. I think itrsquos important that we make sure people understand the parameters within which we are working so we can have some sensible conversations and that we try and accommodate as much as we can in there.Meanwhile, a major operation is underway to get the students back to their classrooms at the beginning of February.The Chief Executive said: ldquoWe put in arrangements for  plus pupils to be accommodated at locations in Peebles, Galashiels Academy and the Langlee complex.ldquoThat has been generally very successfully and the feedback from that has been positive. I absolutely acknowledge that itrsquos not perfect but it has done the job we needed it do to.Senior students are currently sitting prelim exams in the Sports Complex and this will continue until the end of January.Temporary classroom units are being erected within the school grounds and pupils are to be accommodated in unaffected areas of the building.ldquoThere are still huge amounts of work going on and we will go right up to the wire but Irsquom confident we will achieve it, added Ms Logan.The Council has decided on a phased approach with S to S students starting on Monday, February  and S to S working from home and ing the following day.Ms Logan said that there has been ldquocompromises in the education offer over the last few weeks but is assuring parents that from the beginning of February it will be ldquobusiness as usual.Demolition work on the damaged building has been completed and restricted access has been implemented.The council boss has assured parents that children will only be able to access safe routes throughout the school building.Ms Logan added: ldquoOne of the things we did lose in the fire was the vast majority of pupil toilets so what wersquove now got on site is the long term temporary arrangements supplemented over the course of January.To ensure pupil safety, traffic will enter the site from a new access via Craigerne Road located at the back of the school.Ms Logan is meeting with insurers this week to discuss a settlement figure which will help form the direction of the future of Peebles High School.She added: ldquoAll of what we are doing is going to be sustainable for whatever we do in terms of the proper rebuild."What Irsquom trying to reassure you is that wersquore not doing things that are very temporary, whatever we do, we will be looking to the future.Community councillor Graham Mackie commended the local authority on doing a ldquoremarkable job and said any criticism of the Council during this trying time was unnecessary.He said: ldquoIt has been thought for several years that we needed a completely new high school but possibly therersquos a silver lining here in that we can end up with a high school that will meet the needs of the current population."But the council chief told members that ldquoessentially this is the replacement.She explained: ldquoWhen it comes to looking at high schools and replacement we would always look to retain what is still workable."In the case of the bits we are talking about in terms of Peebles High site they are really not that old. The Millennium Wing meets the standards that would be required in a new building. There would be very little point in wasting money knocking down something that works really well. It will be a modern fit for the future school.

title: work-start-three-new-social-housing-developments
story: BOSSES at Scottish Borders Housing Association have announced that work is about to start on three new developments across the region.In a bid to ease the areas social housing waiting lists, SBHA will be building  new homes in Oxton, Kelso and Peebles.Contractors Morris  Spottiswood have now been appointed to build four three-bed family homes at Heriotfield, Oxton.And Stewart  Shields have been chosen to build  three-bed family homes at Tweed Court in Kelso as well as six cottage flats in Glensax Road, Peebles.Chief Executive Julia Mulloy told us: ldquoHousing is a fundamental need, and the demand for quality affordable housing is a major concern facing communities across the Scottish Borders."We are delighted to increase our contribution to meeting this need, and to play our part in delivering more homes in the region."Our new homes are modern, comfortable, secure and energy efficient, as well as being creatively designed to be sympathetic to their surroundings.ldquoTogether with homes already completed in Hawick, Galashiels and Earlston, these new developments will bring the total number of new homes built by SBHA to , alongside extensive refurbishment to bring  homes back into use.ldquoWe look forward to working with partners to deliver more homes in the coming years to meet growing demand and strengthen the affordable housing offer in the Scottish Borders across all communities.The three new developments are part of SBHAs commitment to meet the growing need for affordable housing in the Borders, as well as contributing to the Scottish Governmentrsquos target of , new affordable homes by .The builds will be funded in part through grants from the Scottish Government via Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Strategic Housing Investment Plan.Councillor Mark Rowley, spokesman for Business and Economic Development, said: ldquoEvery new affordable home to be built in the Scottish Borders should be celebrated."They deliver economic benefits to local sub-contractors and businesses and bring opportunities for local people and families and create opportunities for people to move here and contribute to le in the Borders.ldquoIt is vital to our economy that we meet the housing needs of our working age population so I am delighted that this construction programme has been supported by the funding available through Scottish Borders Councilrsquos Strategic Housing Investment Plan.

title: good-behaviour-order-21-year-old-following-bust-up
story: A PEEBLES man who was involved in a bust-up with the mother of his young child has been ordered to be of good behaviour for the next four months at Selkirk Sherf Court.Twenty one year old Brandon Bisset pleaded guilty to shouting and swearing and struggling with his partner at a house in Dalatho Crescent, Peebles, on the morning of Tuesday, November .Alan Wickham, prosecuting, said a verbal altercation took place while they were out for a walk when the woman said she planned to go for a night out over the festive period.A struggle took place when they got back to the house with Bisset taking a young child from the womans arms.Defence lawyer Colin Severin said his client now lived with his parents and the relationship was over.He added that Bisset had regretted his actions and the fact the matter had ended up in court.

title: good-behaviour-order-pensioners-clash
story: A PENSIONER who admitted behaving in a threatening and abusive manner towards his -year-old partner has been ordered to be of good behaviour for the next four months at Selkirk Sherf Court.Seventy-two-year-old Kenneth Cooper pleaded guilty to acting in an aggressive manner and shouting offensive comments during the bust-up at a house in Stichill Road, Ednam, on November .The offence was also racially and domestically aggravated.The court heard that on the day in question the couple had been out together and had ed home and the woman had gone upstairs for a sleep.When she came back down at pm Cooper was lying on the living room floor.Depute fiscal Alan Wickham said the woman was concerned for him but realised he was intoxicated.When Cooper was aroused he began swearing at her and told her to go back to Yorkshire.Mr Wickham said the abuse continued when Cooper went to a bedroom and continued ranting before it stopped at around pm.The court was told the woman challenged Cooper about his behaviour at am the following day but he was dismissive about it and that is when the woman sent an email to Police Scotland requesting assistance.Mr Wickham concluded that the woman had asked for Cooper to stay away from her and the house, which is in joint ownership, is now the subject of civil proceedings.Defence lawyer Colin Severin said his client had been acting as the womans carer.But an argument had developed between the pair when she was "griping about him getting a job" which Mr Severin said Cooper took issue with considering he is  years old.He added: "This culminated in the outburst which he regrets."Sentence was deferred until May  for good behaviour when the imposition of a Non-Harassment Order will be considered.

title: co-op-promises-support-nine-borders-good-causes
story: BORDERS charities are set to get a funding boost thanks to a multi-million pound community fund.Groups from across the Borders will be able to access their share of millions of pounds of charitable donations made by Co-op members using their membership cards.Nine organisations in the Borders, such as Works+, the Rural Scottish WI, Lauder Out of School Club and Beyond Earlston, will receive a cut of any money raisedselected by Co-op members.In order for a group to access this fund, they first need to be chosen by a Co-op member as their selected charity to support.Everytime a Co-op member shops or uses the supermarkets funeral services, as well as personal benefits, one per cent of their spend goes into the community fund which helps support local good causes.Last year charities in the Borders were given pound, from the Co-ops community fund.Nick Crofts, President of the Co-op Council, whose representatives are voted for by the millions of members it represents said: "As a member-owned business with a presence in every community across the UK, the Co-op is continuing to create value for millions of members and thousands of local causes."By becoming a Co-op member not only are you receiving great personal rewards and benefits, you are directly helping to support vital community groups in your area."Rebecca Birkbeck, Director of Community and Shared Value at the Co-op said: "Thanks to our members since  more than pound million has been raised for over , causes that make a real dference in their local communities."Whether it is by protecting and improving community spaces, helping people reach their full potential by developing their skills, or promoting health and wellbeing, the money generated by our Local Community Fund changes lives in communities across the UK."For more information on Co-op membership, visit your local Co-op branch or head to https:www.coop membership

title: labour-hustings-kick-start-leadership-race
story: The Labour leadership race will explode into le on Saturday as the first regional hustings take place.Early front-runner Sir Keir Starmer and self-styled left-wing candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey are among those seeking support to take over from Jeremy Corbyn as party leader.Mrs Long-Bailey and shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry officially launched their campaigns to lead Labour on Friday night.Backbenchers Jess Phillips and Lisa Nandy are also in the race to succeed Mr Corbyn in the ballot that will be decided in early April.--vw,vw,px, px"Emily Thornberry launches her campaign for Labour Party leadership at the Guildford Waterside Centre --Setting out her stall in her hometown of Guildford, Ms Thornberry warned that Labour faces ldquoa long, tough road back to power after the party suffered its worst general election defeat since .The Islington South and Finsbury MP, who narrowly secured the necessary support from MPs to enter the race on Monday, insisted she was the best placed to oust Prime Minister Boris Johnson within five years.She told the PA news agency: ldquoBoris Johnson has all sorts of problems with women.ldquoAnd he is going to have an even bigger oneI become leader of the Labour Party.ldquoI think that he has a problem with women.----ldquoI have spoken to a number of women who have said that the way he deals with them ndash and they are younger women ndash is that he flirts with them.ldquoHe makes light of them and he undermines them. He has problems with women such as myself. title: hilarys-wolf-hall-voted-uks-favourite-historical-novel
story: BOOK lovers behind the Walter Scott Prize for Historical Fiction have announced the winners of their poll to find the UKrsquos favourite historical novel of all time.In first place is Hilary Mantelrsquos masterly Tudor novel Wolf Hall, which also won the very first Walter Scott Prize at the Borders Book Festival in .Coming a close second is the classic Roman adventure story, The Eagle of the Ninth, by Rosemary Sutclf, closely followed by Dorothy Dunnettrsquos, The Game of Kings.The Prize launched its poll in November, asking members of the public to nominate their favourite books on its website.Hundreds of nominations were received, from classics by Walter Scott, Margaret Mitchell, Patrick OrsquoBrian, Robert Louis Stevenson and George Macdonald Fraser, through to beloved authors from the last century including Dorothy Dunnett, Rosemary Sutclf, Umberto Eco, Robert Graves and Mary Renault.More contemporary authors made up the majority of the nominations, including many of those shortlisted by the Walter Scott Prize over the past decade, including Hilary Mantel, Sebastian Barry, Andrew Miller, Eleanor Catton, Patrick Gale, Sarah Waters and Hannah Kent.A shortlist of ten novels was drawn up, and the public were again invited to vote for their favourite.Walter Scott prize co-founder and judge, the Duchess of Buccleuch, told us: "As we all eagerly await the third volume of Hilary Mantelrsquos magnicent saga, Irsquom delighted that readers have voted the first, Wolf Hall, as their favourite historical novel of all time."The Walter Scott Prize launched the poll to find the nationrsquos favourite historical novel to celebrate its tenth year anniversary, so itrsquos a double celebration that the poll has been won by Wolf Hall, the Prizersquos very first winner."Our poll has reminded us all of the riches produced by writers of historical fiction over the centuries, from the works of Walter Scott himself, to milestone books by Rosemary Sutclf and Dorothy Dunnett, right up to the present day with authors such as Sebastian Barry, Eleanor Catton and Sarah Waters gracing the list of nominations."And what a wonderful coincidence that the top three books in our poll are by women."Wolf Hall was published in  to huge critical acclaim, winning many awards including the Man Booker Prize and the Walter Scott Prize.The Eagle of the Ninth by Rosemary Sutclf, published in , received the second highest number of votes.Walter Scott Prize judge Elizabeth Laird is a fan of The Eagle of the Ninth.She said: "What you read and love as a child stays with you for le and that wonderful tale of courage and adventure in the misty north will be with me forever."Devoted Dorothy Dunnett fans nominated many of the Edinburgh-based authorrsquos titles for the poll.The first in the series of the Lymond Chronicles charting Scotlandrsquos turbulent history, The Game of Kings, first published in , was ranked third place in the nationrsquos favourites.

title: scotland-starts-campaign-aims-tourism-boom
story: A MAJOR new tourism drive raced into action last week in a bid to convince visitors to venture south of the capital.A new travel-inspiring website was launched along with a new app, social media campaign and blog to promote both the Scottish Borders and Midlothian.Scotland Starts Here aims to raise the arearsquos profile as a year-round tourism destination .The campaign showcases that Scotlandrsquos identity and soul were born in both the Borders and neighbouring Midlothian.Scotland Starts Here has been developed by the Midlothian Borders Tourism Action Group on behalf of the Scottish Borders Tourism Partnership and Midlothian Tourism Forum.Midlothian Borders Tourism Action Group project manager Jemma Reid told us: ldquoFor many people travelling to Scotland, the Scottish Borders and Midlothian is where their very first experiences, touch-points and memories of Scotland are forged."The launch plays to this and celebrates the unique history and cultural experiences that our region has to offer."We are easily one of the most accessible, most breathtaking and exciting parts of Scotland and we are thrilled that we can now showcase this to the max and through working with local businesses we can take the Scottish Borders and Midlothian to the world.  is the start of some big things for our local tourism industry.Aimed at visitors from the UK, Europe and international markets, the campaign focuses on the four key themes of Hidden Wonders, Active and Outdoors, Food and Drink, and History and Heritage.By putting a spotlight on authentic local experiences and award-winning products and businesses, it will increase potential visitorsrsquo awareness of what the area has to offer for short breaks and holidays.VisitScotland regional director Neil Christison said: ldquoScotland Starts Here is an exciting campaign that will promote the wealth of fantastic experiences on offer in the Scottish Borders and Midlothian and bring to le the stories and people that make the area unique."I would encourage the local industry to get involved in the campaign and help spread the word about the fantastic area where they live and work to visitors at home and abroad."Over the past three years, the Midlothian Borders Tourism Action Group has engaged over  businesses in workshops, training and product development to make them more tourism ready.And many of them were in attendance for last weeks launch at the National Mining Museum of Scotland.

title: galashiels-girlguides-celebrates-100th-birthday
story: GALASHIELS will be celebrating a very important milestone this year as the st Galashiels Girlguiding troop turns .Members of the Guides, Rangers, Brownies and Rainbows will have the chance to celebrate this momentous birthday with events throughout the year, including a fun day in March and an afternoon tea for adult members or those who have volunteered with the group.Irene Sandie from Galashiels Girlguiding told us: "Wersquore hoping that all of the events wersquore having and other activities that we would like to be part of over the year might encourage new adult volunteers to get involved in Girlguiding. Wersquod really like to be able to offer more girls in our area the chance of enjoying Girlguiding and to do this we need more volunteers."Girlguiding has provided young girls and women opportunities to volunteer in their community, learn new skills, visit local and international sites and make new friends.Irene added: "Girlguiding has changed a lot over the last century and more but still adheres to the same aims and ambitions as those of our founding members."We offer a safe, welcoming girl-only space for all girls and young women to try new things, help other people and discover their passions and talent, all while having fun with a group of ready-made friends!"Were dedicated to girls leading the way - they choose activities, challenges and events that inspire them, and our volunteers support them to make it happen. Were always updating and adapting our activities so that theyrsquore relevant to girls today."Through fun, friendship, challenge and adventure we empower girls to find their voice, inspiring them to discover the best in themselves and to make a positive dference in their community."And to mark the occasion, troop leaders are putting together a centenary display to show how Girlguiding has changed in  years.To do this they are asking for any former members or volunteers to send in their pictures of past Guiding activities.Also,you have been involved as an adult volunteer with Galashiels Girlguiding at any time in the last  years, leaders want to hear from you too.To send any old Girlguiding photos, email galashielsdistrict@gmail or get in touch by phone at  .Former volunteers should send your name, unit, date of involvement and contact details to the same address.For more information, visit https:www.girlguidingscotland.org.uk

title: leader january 17 2020
story: Inspirational five-year-old Esmie MacLean who is fundraising to help her brother access expensive autism treatment can teach us all a lesson on altruism.While many children her age would be dreaming of what they want for their birthday # Esmie is six on Sunday # she has signed herself up to run m at this year#s MOK Run, which is no small feat for someone with such little legs.They say that early intervention can be the key to success, and other parents who have tried out the therapies for which Esmie is raising money, speak of outstanding results.It can be very hard to #go public# with such personal family matters, so not only should Esmie be commended, but also her mum and dad, Iona and Scott, who had the courage to talk out for the benefit of their family.Campbeltown always rallies when it comes to such worthwhile causes and every penny counts, so please donate whatever you can.We would like to wish Esmie the very best of luck for the race # and, of course, a very happy birthday on Sunday.

title: former-depute-lord-lieutenant-receives-telegram-queen-diamond-wedding
story: Marlene, , and Stan, , married in  and have four children together ndash now aged between  and . They also have five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren, one of whom is just a few weeks old.The Port Seton couple had a surprise celebration with their loved ones at the Waterside Bistro in Haddington on Boxing Day and were joined by the Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian Michael Williams and deputy Lynn Marshall, who greeted Marlene with a huge bunch of flowers and her very own telegram from Her Majesty The Queen.Marlene told the Courier: ldquoIt was very exciting. I knew that at some point I would have got a telegram but with our anniversary being on Boxing Day, I didnrsquot know when it would be.Marlene, who has always been heavily involved in the community, said she was ldquopassionate about where she lives.She got involved with the villagersquos gala committee when her children were young and went on to serve Cockenzie  Port Seton Community Council for  years.She has also been the chair of Cockenzie and Port Seton In Bloom for  years and was the chair of the community centre advisory committee before there was even a Port Seton Centre.She is still on the management committee for the centre and said she never thought she would live to see the new sports hall that she has passionately campaigned for, which is due to be finished by August.Marlene met her husband Stan, who was living in Leith at the time, ldquoquite by accident, she said.ldquoStanrsquos friendrsquos mother had a hut at the [Seton Sands] caravan site and the boys used to come down at the weekends [from Edinburgh], she said.ldquoI was going down to buy cigarettes for my friend and Stan shouted something out of the window of a car at me, and afterwards we realised we worked quite close to each other.ldquoI worked at the McEwanrsquos brewery [in Fountainbridge] as a telephonist and Stan worked for the North British Rubber Company at the time.ldquoWe used to meet at lunchtime and then Stan got into the habit of coming to Port Seton every weekend. He would just happen to be at the bus station when I finished work with no bus fare.The couple, of Inglis Avenue, married a year later, when Marlene was  and Stan was .Stan worked at Cockenzie Power Station for  years and even helped with the construction of the site before it opened in .He joked: ldquoI helped build it and helped tear it down!Marlene said of their marriage: ldquoWe never thought we would have made it to this milestone. I remember my father saying: lsquoI will give you six months.rsquoldquoWe had a lot of hard times, we were young and foolish and hard up, but for some unknown reason we managed to take the kids on holiday every year and buy them their season tickets for the swimming pool. We had to save all year for them.ldquoFor the young, I would say not to marry young. Irsquom very proud that none of my children have followed in our footsteps.ldquoI would say [in marriage] it is important to always be mindful of one another and try to be toleranthellip never keep an argument going. It is too easy nowadays to walk away but you just have to keep going. I wanted to kill him some days and it was probably likewise but we have had a great le together.ldquoWe feel very lucky to have reached this age and that all of our children have got good lives, and their children are just a delight to have around.In their retirement, Marlene and Stan have travelled most of the Mediterranean and much of Europe together, and enjoy looking after their grandchildren, who all live in the county.

title: first-scots-baby-new-decade-born-port-seton-parents
story: The little boy - whose name has still to be revealed - entered the world at .am todayat the Simpson Centre for Reproductive Health at theRoyal Infirmary of Edinburgh.Weighing in atlbs oz, he is the first child for mother Emma Allan, , and father Cameron Cunningham, , both of Castle Avenue, Post Seton.The parents said they were "delighted" with the new arrival. title: new-mcbrave-games-event-held-musselburgh
story: The action-packed event, called McBrave Games, promises participants a uniquely Scottish experience with events such as tug orsquo war, tossing the caber, putting the shot, the hill race, weechinrsquo the welly and a Highland fling.There will also be a Scottish twist on challenges along the km obstacle course to test participants.The event takes place on Saturday, May , at Newhailes House.Participants can take on the challenge as a solo entrant or enter as a clan of four with colleagues or friends to battle it out to become the laddie or lassie of McBrave Games.Co-founders Jo Dytch and Andrew Hastings are confident the creativity and innovation behind the event will encourage entrants to try something new in .Jo and Andrew bring with them more than  yearsrsquo combined experience in the mass participation space on large-scale events such as Race for Le, Tough Mudder and the -mile Cateran Yomp.Commenting on the inspiration behind the event, Jo said: ldquoScotland is an inspiring and magical place. Bringing the Highland Games to everyone and making it accessible seems only right. ldquoAndrew added: ldquoThe idea of combining an epic obstacle race with the Highland Games really got us excited.ldquoIt has taken us the best part of a year to get the event from a concept ready to go.ldquoWe are both big believers in innovation and the McBrave Games is a new idea that takes the familiar and gives it a unique twist.Participants can register online.

title: future-health-services-east-lothian-discussed-meeting
