title: Iain Macwhirter  Pale and stale Labour is facing a leadership conundrum
story: Ms Phillipsrsquos blunt repudiation of a referendum came on the same day as, and in very similar terms to, Boris Johnsonrsquos letter rejecting Ms Sturgeonrsquos request for a Section  Order.It almost looked like a co-ordinated strike on the nationalist heartland. Both Mr Johnson and Ms Phillips say they want to bring the country together, not ide it ndash and anyway the Nats should be concentrating on education and health.:SNP has no mandate for second independence vote, Jess Phillips insists"@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Who are the Labour leadership contenders ","description": "Who are the Labour leadership contenders ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media ltvZUqv poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ltvZUqv.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Mr Johnson didnrsquot go so far as to ask Scots to ldquobung a bob for a Big Ben bong on Brexit night, but nor was there any hint of federalism or more powers for Holyrood. That boat has sailed.Ms Phillips too is from the branch of Labour thinking that equates nationalism with nativism and racism. She is actually a fairly conventional right-wing Labour politician with a Brummie gloss. ldquoWe want to bring people together, not ide them, she said yesterday,because our compassion doesnrsquot end at an imaginary line on a map.Well, what does end at that line on the map is Labour MPs ndash the party only has one left, Edinburgh Southrsquos Ian Murray. He is standing for the deputy leadership and backing Ms Phillips for Labour leader. If the duo were to win I doubtLabourrsquos fortunes would be greatly enhanced ldquoup here.For a party that is so obsessed by identity, the one they donrsquot seem to recognise as legitimate is Scottishness ndash at least in its political manestations. Ms Phillips dismisses Scottish nationalism with a contempt that would be entirely absent were she talking about Irish nationalism.:Labour leadership: Emily Thornberry edges over line as Clive Lewis pulls out of raceYet identity is the paramount issue in politics following Brexit. Labour is all for multiculturalism, but finds it hard in practice, even with racial identity. As the Labour leadership candidates lined up in all their glory yesterday, I was tempted to say, as Jon Snow of Channel  News said of that Brexit march last year: ldquoIrsquove never seen so many white faces.Only Lisa Nandy can legitimately claim ethnic descent from her father. Such a visual contrast to all those United Colours of Corbyn photo ops during the election.A party which has made a religion of ersity seems set to hand the leadership to Sir Keir Starmer, a wealthy North London barrister, who looks the very image of ldquowhite male privilege that Labour supporters on Twitter love to loathe.For a party that lectures the media, business and academia on gender, the leadership is turning into an intersectional embarrassment. Labour has never had a woman leader, and doesnrsquot seem likely to get one this time. Four out of the five candidates to replace Jeremy Corbyn are female, but the straight white guy is ahead by a mile.Mind you, Mr Starmer, as he would like us to call him, has been given a free pass by some feminists on the grounds that he is the ldquohot ticket. According to commentators like Zoe Williams in the , Sir Keir bears a striking resemblance to Marc Drsquoarcy, the austere-but-sexy human rights lawyer played by Colin Firth in the Bridget Jonesrsquos Diary film franchise.In the salons of North London, this apparently makes the Labour MP less pale, male and stale, and more pale, male and phooar. Mind you, I donrsquot think his looks will set many hearts a-throbbing in the pubs and clubs of Workington and Bolsover.As Shadow Brexit Secretary, Sir Keir was largely responsible for turning Labour into the Remain Party before the General Election. He made clear he would never support even a Labour Brexit. That convinced tens of thousands of le-long Labour voters to turn to Mr Johnson on the grounds that only the Tories were listening to them.But thatrsquos all water under the bridge now. Itrsquos time to ldquomove on. Forget Brexit. After all, Labour won the argument, didnrsquot they Aware of the Islington millionaire tag, Sir Keir has been trying to burnish his working class image. He is of relatively humble origins, stood on Wapping picket lines and has advised the National Union of Mineworkers. In the run-up to Mondayrsquos ballot, the leadership hopefuls engaged in a a replay of the Monty Python northern bores sketch.Lawyer Rebecca Long-Baileyhas been massaging her CV to include a spell in NHS, employment when she wasnrsquot formally employed there.Emily Thornberry has a sister who is a bus driver, which came as news to me. Though this is somewhat cancelled out, class-wise, by her being in possession of the title ldquoLady Nugee, courtesy of her marriage to the Honourable Christopher Nugee, a High Court judge.:Labour announces three-month leadership campaign with Jeremy Corbyns successor named on April Now, these things shouldnrsquot matter when deciding a party leadership. Labour should be choosing the candidate best able to lead the party to victory, on merit, rather than someone who fits a hackneyed image of proletarian virtue. Race should be irrelevant in a party that believes in equality.But of course in the Labour Party of today it so obviously does matter. Labour has been hypnotised by identity politics and sees everything through racial and gender eyeglasses. It requires of other organisations that ious minority and gender boxes are ticked. But when it comes to their own leader, well, itrsquos complicated. And when it comes to Scotland, itrsquos more complicated still.Ms Phillips is essentially standing as the only leadership candidate who speaks the language of the working class. ldquoI love the people I grew up among, she says, ldquoand I think that they can tell. The implication is that other candidates donrsquot have this relationship with the voters.Mind you, Irsquom not sure that applies to the  per cent of her constituents in Birmingham Yardley who voted for Brexit. Ms Phillips is another dedicated Remainer, who seems to think that the wishes of Labour voters only countthey agree with her.Like many Labour MPs, Ms Phillips spends most of her time in the looking-glass world of Twitter. Who is the proliest of them all  She asks her , followers. Only you, Jess, only you. At least in England.Read more: Phillips:I become Labour leader, party will be  per cent committed to Union

title: barrhead-travel-founder-vindicated-winning-unfair-dismissal-claim
story: Mr Munro left the business in November,  - just nine months after selling up to US travel giants Travel Leaders Group the previous February.And the -year-old, who initially stayed on as chairman after the buyout, pursued an employment tribunal against his former firm amid claims his dismissal process was a "sham".His position as chairman was made redundant a month after he was offered a -hours-a-month contract to carry out "special projects" with no continuity of service.Employment Judge Lucy Wiseman said that an offer of alternative employment to Mr Munro on "unreasonable terms" and a flawed appeal process "rendered the dismissal of the claimant unfair".Mr Munro took his case to the tribunal hoping to be reinstated as Barrhead chairman, insisting during the tribunal that he ldquowas not here for the money.:I just want to work again, says Barrhead Travel founderBut it was ruled ldquonot practicable after Ms Wiseman took into account a breakdown in the relationship between Mr Munro and the TLG management team.While he was not awarded compensation, he will be paid pound, ldquoin respect of the balance of the payment of notice on top of a redundancy package of pound, which has already been transferred.Mr Munro, who started Barrhead Travel in , with just one shop and four members of staff, said that there may be further legal action in the future ldquoThis has been a harrowing, emotional and stressful time," he said.ldquoI have had to endure the ordeal of having my lersquos achievements being traduced in public."The former executive, who grew Barrhead Travel to become one of the UKs largest independent travel agencies, with more than  stores employing  workers added: ldquoIn my career I have been awarded three letime achievement awards ndash two in the UK travel industry and a third from the Glasgow Chamber of Commerce. These mean the world to me.ldquoAnd my reputation was brought into questionhellip I am delighted the tribunal has vindicated me.A findings of fact statement from the tribunal said that TLG understood that he had started to step away from the day-to-day running of the business after the sale while he remained in an ambassadorial role of chairman and founder.The statement said Mr Munro was not initially expected to work full time or for a set number of hours but would be paid pound per hour for anything he did outside his "special projects" role for TLG in the UK. It was anticipated he would receive no more than pound, per year in the role which was to look at opportunities for growth but TLG did not want him directly involved in Barrhead Travel work.But the tribunal heard that TLG chief executive Ninan Chacko had become "alarmed" that Mr Munro was averaging seven hours per day which "exceeded what had been expected" and had focussed "almost entirely" on Barrhead Travel activities.Barrhead Travel TV advert from By May, , Mr Munro was given a -hours-a-month contract was offered with maximum pay of pound a month and his responsibilities were for projects directed by TLGs global head of supply relationships, Andrew Winterton.Mr Munro said he had "quite a lump in my throat" when the contract stated there would be no period of continuous employment.The findings of fact document said Mr Munro felt he was being asked to "effectively forego" the last  years of continuous service in exchange for a fresh start under the new arrangement.The following month, TLG told Mr Munro of Mr Chackos preliminary view that there was no longer a need for a chairman and that during a consultation process he would be informed of any alternative roles that may be on offer to avoid making him redundant.:Boss of firm who bought Barrhead Travel planned to sack founderBy July he had been made redundant as chairman of Barrhead Travel, and received a payment of pound, while being offered work on special projects on a consultancy basis.Mr Munro appealed saying he found it impossible to continue with special projects while at home, and argued he still had something to contribute to Barrhead Travel. The tribunal findings of fact said that after a discussion, Mr Chacko referred to Mr Munro as having been "disruptive" and the appeal was rejected."Mr Chacko did not consider reinstatement was an option for the claimant because his role no longer existed," the tribunal was told. "The claimantrsquos previous actings had been disruptive and detrimental to the business ."TLG had paid for the whole Barrhead business with a management team, and the claimantrsquos reinstatement would be at odds with the ability of the management team to be successful. "According to the tribunal papers, Barrhead Travel argued that the removal of the role of chairman was a "legitimate and rational business decision" and acted "reasonably" in offering Mr Munro a new role.The firm argued thatMr Munro had accepted the consultancy agreement, he would have suffered no harm financially because he had already received a full statutory redundancy payment.But Mr Munros representatives argued to the tribunal that his ambassadorial role had not been made redundant and the outcome of dismissal had been predetermined.Ms Wiseman said it was "clear" that Mr Munro found it "very dficult" to step away from Barrhead Travel.She could not accept that his dismissal was predetermined but said that the offer of alternative employment was "unreasonable" because it omitted continuity of service.And she said there was a "flaw" in the appeal procedure in which an executive had "accepted at face value" what Mr Chacko had told him about Mr Munro being disruptive and allowed this to influence his decision.But she felt that the reason for Mr Munro not accepting the new contract was he had lost trust in Mr Chacko and others in the organisation.And she believed thata fair procedure had been followed, there was a % chance Mr Munro would still have been dismissed.Barrhead Travel declined to comment.

title: glasgows-cop26-might-cost-us-cant-afford-parochial
story: It was dficult to tease out a more expansive answer from the group of Europeans ndash Danish, German and Swedish ndash because they clearly felt the UK was suffering enough and didnt want to rub it in.Yesterday the Scottish Parliament announced it would no longer fly the European flag above Holyrood as the Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom said she had bunged pound towards a crowdfunder to have Big Ben bong when the UK leaves the EU at pm on January .Its all getting frighteningly real.When the country is iously viewed as a laughing stock and to be pitied, it surely can only help that we have a major event coming up, giving Scotland the chance to shine on the world stage.And not just any event ndash one of the most signicant the UK has seen. Large enough to knock the Olympics and the Commonwealth Games into a cocked hat.Yet the backlash against COP , the United Nations Climate Change Summit, has already begun.It was revealed on Wednesday that the event, to be held in Glasgow at the SEC Campus on the banks of the River Clyde, is expected to cost hundreds of millions of pounds in policing costs. It was a wonder that anyone was surprised.Glasgow will host up to  world leaders and , delegates.Its due to be the largest policing operation the UK has seen - this sort of thing doesnt come cheap.Calum Steele, the General Secretary of the Scottish Police Federation, spoke positively about the event on BBC Radio Scotland on Wednesday morning, saying there had been nothing like it in Scotland or even the UK before.Mr Steele described it asmore signicant than the Olympic Games or Commonwealth Games and would require the largest mass mobilisation of UK police the country has seen.The G summits, he said, "will pale into insignicance."He went into further details. Police Scotland will be unable to manage the event alone. The country will host leaders from the US, Russia, China and Israel, all of whom will demand their own safety and security considerations.Alongside leaders, delegates and guests, the police service has to accommodate hundreds of protestors. Economic opportunities must be leapt on, he added. Scotland will be in the "spotlight of the world for those two weeks."He pointed to the very clear potential economic benefits for Glasgow and for Scotland.Yet even Mr Steele, after these positive sentiments, yesterday on Twitter shared a video of buckets collecting water pouring through the roof of Paisley Police Office. "Itrsquos not unreasonable to ask," he posted alongside the image, "If we canrsquot even fix a roof how the hell will [COP] be paid for "Nicola Sturgeon has called for Westminster to honour a pledge made to fund the event, given the UK is the host.Conversely, GMB Scotland called for Glasgow to reject the chance to host the summit. Its secretary, Gary Smith, said the costs would "sicken frontline council staff and struggling local communities.""The best thing government could do for Glasgow," he said, "Is to ditch hosting the COP and instead invest the money in dealing with the state of the city."Its hardly the London Garden Bridge project, which, in case weve forgotten, saw poundm wasted, including pound, on a gala for the abandoned scheme. If nothing , it all served to show the strength of positive feeling towards Joanna Lumley, a vocal campaigner for this extraordinary white elephant, as she should surely have lost her national treasure status over the shameful incident.There is a string of other grossly wasteful examples of public funds. In  it emerged the frequently delayed NHS  new telecommunication and patient information system was going to cost poundm more than originally forecast.The HS railway plans have been described as at risk of becoming "a bottomless pit for taxpayersrsquo money". Finance Secretary Derek Mackay told MSPs last year that taxpayers were picking a bill of an poundm for two CalMac ferries, which look likely to be delivered four years late, due to "disastrous" previous management at Ferguson Marine in Port Glasgow.There was much back and forth over whether the legacy of Glasgows Commonwealth Games was all it was cracked up to be. The taxpayer spent pound. million on Glasgow  and all anyone remembers is the dancing teacake, it goes.There lies part of the problem. The public is used to politicians chucking its money away - whether on good faith projects such as the Games or ludicrous Boris Johnson vanity projects.Its important that the spending of taxpayers money is carefully scrutinised and those responsible for the mismanagement of publicly funded projects held to account.The public is protective of its taxes, people work hard and want afor their investment, and they do not automatically trust politicians to use their money wisely. Hence the almighty stooshie over Glasgows Lord Provost spending her civic allowance on shoes.Hence repeated grumbles when politicians head off on so-called junkets abroad. Last year the First Minister received pelters after travelling to Paris and straight on to North America.This was at the same time Lib Dem MP Angela Smith referred to people of a "funny tinge". My personal preference is for outward-looking politicians who want to make strong global links... not those who blurt out racist epithets without a second thought.Climate change is the most important issue of the day and this is an extraordinary chance for Glasgow, Scotland and the UK to be seen to be leading the way.Squabbling over the costs of policing an event with myriad economic opportunities for the city is such an insular, short sighted way of thinking.This is an international event and we must think internationally. It may be costly but the one thing we cannot afford is to be parochial when all eyes are on us, finally, for something of global importance.

title: scottish-government-introduce-laws-tackling-unregulated-beauticians
story: Such procedures are currently not regulated and can be carried out by anyone.In a consultation document, the Government said there is a ldquogrowing risk as the number of unregulated premises ndash including beauty salons, aesthetic clinics, hairdressers and pharmacies ndash offering the treatments is increasing.:Celebrity culture and social media fuelling rise in young Scots using injectable tan and steroidsThe paper highlights the potential for the procedures to go wrong and the possibility that permanent damage can be caused.Ministers plan to bring in legislation to introduce a licensing scheme for people who are not healthcare professionals and carry out non-surgical treatments which penetrate the skin.They have stopped short of a ban, despite the Scottish Cosmetic Interventions Expert Group effectively calling for such a move by saying the procedures should only be provided ldquoon or behalf of a regulated healthcare professional.The consultation document states: ldquoWe consider that a blanket ban on non-medical professionals carrying out non-surgical cosmetic procedures could be dficult to enforce and might drive unregulated providers underground.In , the law was changed to ensure independent clinics run by a doctor, dentist, nurse, midwe or dental technician had to register with Healthcare Improvement Scotland before they could legally provide cosmetic procedures.The Scottish Government wants pharmacies to be included in this group as part of the proposed legislative changes.Public health minister Joe FitzPatrick said: ldquoWe are committed to patient safety and want to ensure that all those who carry out non-surgical procedures, such as dermal fillers or lip enhancements, are competent and that the treatments take place in safe and hygienic premises.:Keeping the cowboys out of cosmetic treatmentsldquoWe plan to introduce regulations later this year and invite members of the public and interested parties to give their views as part of the consultation on our proposals.ldquoIn the meantime, we urge anyone considering any kind of cosmetic surgery to visit the Health Improvement Scotland website for regulated and approved providers.The consultation opened on Friday and runs until the end of April.

title: edinburgh-airport-celebrates-record-year-thanks-new-international-routes
story: The airport celebrated its busiest year in history with ,, passengers travelling through, up . per centon .December passenger figures for  were also up on the same month the previous year, rising . per centto ,,.:Glasgow Airport to fly worlds largest passenger plane on year-round routeThe international market saw a . per centincrease on December , with strong growth in the short-haul segment.However, the domestic market was down . per centon December  after Ryanair cut the Stansted route from October  and Flybe stopped operating its route to East Midlands that month.Edinburgh Airport said it had the busiest ever year for a Scottish airport.Chief executive Gordon Dewar said: ldquoWersquore delighted to deliver a record year for any Scottish airport as passengers continued to take advantage of new routes, new airlines and the opportunity to expand their horizons and travel the world.ldquoWe never lose sight of the fact that the airport is a conduit to a whole host of things. We play our part in tourism, business, education, research and culture. We are that gateway to Scotland and to the world, and direct connectivity to countries across the world plays a huge part in that success.ldquoClearly, we want to see that success continue to benefit Edinburgh and Scotland, and travel will always be a part of that, but we do have a responsibility to manage that success in a sustainable manner.ldquoWe appreciate that we need to show leadership in this area and we are currently finalising a strategy which will map out our approach to operations at Edinburgh to make them even more sustainable than they already are. We look forward to sharing that strategy and engaging with our communities on it.While international passenger numbers rose .per cent on the previous year in , domestic passenger numbers were down . per centon .:Preferred bidder chosen to take over Prestwick AirportThe international market was boosted by several new routes and an increase in services last year.They included Ryanairrsquos routes to Luxembourg and Bucharest, easyJet, which introduced a new route to Verona, and Wizz Air, which started four new routes to Budapest, Bucharest, Warsaw and Gdansk.Delta increased its service to JFK from five times a week to daily while Turkish Airlines did the same with its Istanbul service.

title: parades-orange-walks-republic-marches-rose-20-last-year
story: Iain Livingstone, Chief Constable of Police Scotland, said around , such events took place last year, rising from ,.It came as he outlined the challenges facing officers across Scotland as the police struggle to deal with a funding shortfall.Mr Livingstone said Police Scotlandrsquos capital budget is ldquoderisory, while savings of pound million have been made every year since the creation of the single force in .And he insisted ldquoacute operational demand will continue over  due to Brexit and events such as COP, a major climate change summit to be hosted in Glasgow in November.Mr Livingstone said early assessments indicate the policing costs of COP could potentially exceed pound million.He said it will be ldquoone of the biggest events ever hosted in the UK, with a signicant number of heads of state expected to attend, as well as tens of thousands of delegates over a two-week period.Policing requirements would be ldquofar more signicant than past events, including the G summit at Gleneagles in .At a board meeting of the Scottish Police Authority, Mr Livingstone said accommodation for officers alone could cost ldquotens of millions.He added: ldquoCandidly, it is my professional opinion that any suggestion that the climate change conference will not impact on the wider community of Scotland is fancul.An estimated , people, including around  world leaders, will attend the UNrsquos COP summit over  days in November.For the duration of this, the conference site at the Scottish Events Campus in Finnieston will become international territory.Elsewhere, Mr Livingstone pointed to the rise in parades and marches, which also put pressure on police officers.He said: ldquoIn , by way of example, the number of parades ndash Orange walks, republican marches and such like ndash which Police Scotland were notied of increased by almost %, from around , to ,, often resulting in a large policing response necessary to maintain order and protect the public.Deputy Chief Constable Will Kerr warned this years parades season could once again be "challenging".He said there had been "signicant tension" around some marches in , with a number of events requiring a police presence of more than .He said he feared that could continue to be the case this year.Mr Kerr, who spent almost three decades as a police officer in Belfast, said his "intuition" tells him it is "going to be a challenging year around the parading season".The force had to call in riot police, mounted officers, a police helicopter and dog units to deal with "signicant disorder" at a march in Govan at the end of August last year when "disruptive" counter-protesters met a planned Irish Unity march.Another march saw a policeman injured when he was struck by a pyrotechnic thrown by a protester.Auditors previously suggested Police Scotland will need an additional pound million over the next two years to avoid slashing officer numbers.There have been warnings that up to  officers will need to be cut to balance the books.However, Mr Livingstone said it was not appropriate to begin reducing officer numbers in March, as he had planned, due to the upcoming events and pressures.David Crichton, vice chair of the Scottish Police Authority, said there is a ldquostructural deficit in the policing budget.He said: ldquoItrsquos simple arithmetic, itrsquos not complicated mathematics.ldquoWith almost % of the budget allocated to officer and staff costs it does mean that dficult choices are going to have to be made over the next weeks and months. Dficult choices by government, by the authority, and by Police Scotland.ldquoFrankly, current officer numbers are not sustainable within the existing budget, so something has to change on that front.ldquoThe deficit is simply going to continue to increasesomething does not change.

title: hemp-suppositories-ease-widows-constant-orgasms-smear-injury
story: Maria, a -year-old from East Dunbartonshire, has been told by NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde that they are unable to prescribe the medicinal cannabis product because there is not enough evidence to support it.The hemp suppositories were recommended by Dr David Goldmeier, an NHS consultant and UK expert in persistent genital arousal disorderat St Marys Hospital in London who the health board referred Maria to for treatment last year.: Orgasm hell for widow after botched smear test damages nerveShe said the effects have been "le-changing" in relieving the excruciating discomfort caused by a trapped pudendal nerve which was damaged during a routine cervical examination at Stobhill Hospital in Glasgow in September .As well as being effective, the suppositories - which cost just pound for a pack of  - are also much cheaper than the treatments she has been previously offered, including pound tubes of topical gabapentin and pound bottles of Ichthammol lotion.She has also endured "painful and humiliating" nerve block injections in a bid to numb the area, but the effects would often wear off within hoursthey worked at all. She has even suffered from disturbing hallucinations - including seeing her GP "melt" in front of her - as a result of side effects from tranquilisers prescribed to calm her.However,Maria wants to continue taking the hemp suppositories she will face a pound a month bill for the  packs she needs.The mother-of-three said: "Why should I be paying the bill when I didnt cause the problem  This was inflicted on me by the NHS so the NHS should be paying for it."Its been recommended by the very specialist they sent me to - that I had to fight to be sent to - and now theyre ignoring his advice."The condition has calmed down a lot. My own GP says shes never seen me looking better in the past two years than I do now. Theyre the only thing thats worked. For me, its amazing not to have feeling down there."The Herald first revealed Marias story in July last year when she spoke of how PGAD meant simple activities such as driving over a pothole or using an escalator could trigger embarrassing orgasms.The condition and the memory of the initial injury have been so debilitating that Dr Goldmeier also recommended a course of eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing , a form of psychotherapy more commonly prescribed to alleviate trauma in people who have suffered abuse or served in warzones.: New fathers shouldnt be made to feel like a waste of space on the maternity wardThere is a two-year waiting list on the NHS, however, so Maria is paying for it privately through her health insurance.The same is not possible for the suppositories, however, as current UK guidelines on medicinal cannabis state that it should only be considered where there is "clear published evidence of benefit".Currently, that only applies to rare forms of epilepsy in children and young adults, chemotherapy-induced nausea, and muscle spasms in multiple sclerosis.However, when Marias case was raised with Jeane Freeman in December by her then-MP, Jo Swinson, the Scottish Health Secretary said that exceptions could be made for so-called unlicensed products on a "named patient basis" where "there is a clinical need which cannot be met by a licensed medicine and where established treatment options have been exhausted".Maria has now written back to Ms Freeman begging for her help "as a woman" with the health board after her request to be granted the suppositories on this basis was refused.She wrote: "I have been prescribed an unending list of medication since December , with insufferable side effects. I do not believe that I should be required to tolerate anything producing such side effects when the condition was not of natural cause, but inflicted upon me by the NHS...it is ludicrous that I should be expected to pay for these in order to live a quasi-normal le."If the health board will not supply these, then there is a moral obligation for them to fund me in advance in order that I may purchase them myself. At a cost of pound for ten, and with no cure for this condition, I could require them for  or  years or however many years I may have left to live.": GP shortages closes all of NHS Greater Glasgow and Clydes nighttime out-of-hours unitsIn a further twist in the saga, Maria was shocked when she requested copies of her medical records from the health boards legal office in October last year only to be accidentally sent the notes for another female patient from Paisley who had been the victim of a sex attack, including the womans name, address and a copy of police reports on the assault.The incident has been reported to the Information Commissioner as a breach of data protection.Maria has yet to receive copies of the information she asked for about her own case, however.She said: "Imagine I knew the woman  Imaginethe attacker was named and I knew him  The incompetence is staggering."A spokesperson for NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde said: "We understand this is a dficult time for this patient. We are working hard to provide her with the best care possible."Prescription of cannabis-based products is subject to considerable regulation. We are currently looking into the patientrsquos request and will be in touch with her next week once we have explored all options."We take the confidentiality of our patientsrsquo health records very seriously. This was an isolated incident where a set of health records of another inidual was released in error. Once we became aware of this, we immediately informed the inidual and apologised."We also reported the breach to the Information Commissioners Office. We have taken measures to ensure this doesnrsquot happen again. We have re-trained staff who release health records and added an additional check by senior staff before any records are released."A Scottish Government spokesmansaid: ldquoThe Health Secretary continues to express her deepest sympathies for the dficulties and extremely distressing symptoms which Maria is experiencing ndash and she will say again in her reply to Mariarsquos most recent letter that she absolutely understands Mariarsquos concerns.ldquoMinisters cannot make or influence prescribing decisions. The decision on whether to prescribe any medicine for a patient, and which medicine to prescribe, is entirely one for clinicians to make."If a clinician on the specialist register were to prescribe an approved cannabis-based product for medicinal use using an NHS prescription, it would be dispensed free of charge in Scotland.

title: cop26-cost-policing-climate-summit-glasgow-could-exceed-200m
story: Iain Livingstone said the figure is a ldquovery indicative estimate of the cost of policing the UN summit in the city in November.An estimated , people, including around  world leaders, are aid and specialist support.He compared the conference to the massive security operations required at previous high-profile events in Scotland.He added: ldquoI know from personal experience having been assessment at this time.Meanwhile, Assistant Chief Constable Bernard Higgins told SPA members about some the challenges the event poses to police.The summit runs from November  to November , but he Evenyou go back to the London Olympics it will be on parallel with that in terms of officers numbers, but the unique nature of this makes the threat level quite dferent.ldquoThe absolute reality isthe safety and security plan is not in place,it is not robust,it is not going to deliver what it seeks to deliver, then the conference simply cannot happen because it would not be a safe and secure venue.Mr Higgins said protests at the conference would not just be about climate change, saying: ldquoSome of the attending nations will attract protests because of their domestic policies, because of who they are.: review: The year the world woke up to climate changeHe also spoke about the mass climate march that will ldquomost likely take place in Glasgow to coincide with the event, but could be held in Edinburgh.Mr Higgins said: ldquoWe could reasonably anticipate in excess of , people, thatrsquos a very conservative estimate because when it happened in Madrid it was reported it was , people that took to the streets.Mr Livingstone said his ldquokey priorities are to police the event ldquowhile of course ensuring that the citizens of Scotland are effectively protected and policed while we meet the policing requirements of the conference.But he added: ldquoIt is my professional opinion that any suggestion that the climate change conference will not impact on the wider community of Scotland is fancul.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: SCOTTISH Tory leadership contender Jackson Carlaw has been excitedly retweeting endorsements, we see. Like the one from Jackie McCamon, a Tory byelection candidate in Dumfries. ldquoJackie would be a first class Cllr. Delighted to have her on #TeamJackson, he gushed. Alas, the photo Ms McCamon posted of her nomination paper clearly showed she had written the wrong name, one ldquoJackson Carlow. Part of #TeamJockson perhaps UnappreciativeTALKING of endorsements, spare a thought for Glasgow councillor Eva Murray, who also took to Twitter to back a candidate. On Thursday, she declared she was ldquoproud to nominate friend and fighter Pauline McNeill to be Scottish Labourrsquos next deputy leader, as she was ldquocommitted to listening to the grassroots, Cllr Murray gushed. Letrsquos hope Ms McNeill listens better than she types. The Glasgow MSP replied: ldquoThanks Eva very much unappreciated.Ballantyne boostMR Carlaw looks like a shoo-in rep replace Ruth Davidson as Public Tory No in Scotland. Or at least thatrsquos what Unspun thought until his launch, when in walked perpetual candidate Iain lsquoBlue Jonahrsquo McGill. The former Edinburgh postie has tried in vain to get elected to Holyrood, Westminster and Brussels a dozen times. Superstitious observers declared thatMr McGill was part of Team Jackson, it was definitely time to bet on Michelle Ballantyne.Looking pastyELSEWHERE, Ian Murray, Scotlandrsquos sole remaining Labour MP, launched his campaign to be the UK partyrsquos deputy leader at his old school in Edinburghrsquos Wester Hailes. In a lovely touch, he was introduced by Danny Costello, his -year-old former deputy principal. ldquoFrom the outset, Ian fully and successfully engaged in the whole le of the school, the curricular and extra-curricular side of things, from music to PE, said Mr Costello, beaming with pride. He added: ldquoThis was before he discovered Greggs.Labour valuesMR Murray later reminisced about his time as a schoolboy entrepreneur, selling t-shirts through a Young Enterprise scheme. ldquoWe did very, very well out of it ndash the way the process worked is you sold shares to friends, family, teachers and colleagues, you used that money to buy stock, you designed them, you advertised, you marketed, you then sold it all and you paid the shareholders back, he said. Before adding: ldquoWe forgot about the last bit.Top prioritiesMORE news from the pound. million Citizens Assembly, the talking shop boldly reimagining Scotlandrsquos future. Last week, Unspun noted an aspiration for the country to ldquobe free of Nicola Sturgeon among the hundreds of membersrsquo ideas for ldquothe Scotland we are seeking to build. Other highlights include a plea for a football team ldquothat can reach the world cup finals and a noble desire to ldquomake fags and alcohol cheaper. Itrsquos enough to make the heart swell with pride.

title: scientists-seeking-people-orkney-shetland-ancestry-latest-phase-gene-study
story: People with at least two grandparents who were born on the islands are eligible to take part in the research, which seeks to pinpoint the links between rare genetic mutations and a range of diseases from diabetes to multiple sclerosis .The unique genetic identity of those with Northern Isles ancestry with its heavy Viking heritage offers a rare opportunity to give a detailed picture on how genes are implicated in health.: Surpise as common bacteria in probiotic shows promise to halt Parkinsons diseaseResearch published last year revealed that the island of Yell in Shetland had the highest concentration of Scandinavian genes ndash  per cent ndash anywhere in the world, except Scandinavia.The VIKING II study, led by Edinburgh University, is not restricted to current inhabitants of the islands whose parents or grandparents were born there, however.Northern Isles diaspora across Scotland, the rest of the UK and worldwide can also take part.There are known to be substantial clusters of people descended from Shetlanders and Orcadians in Chicago, Saskatchewan in Canada, and Dunedin in New Zealand.The researchers want to recruit , new participants for the study, which first began  years ago, to maximise their chances of strong results.Lead researcher Professor Jim Wilson said: ldquoWersquove been studying the populations in Orkney and Shetland for about  years now and our preliminary results show that they both have unique gene pools which have some iants that are really magnied in frequency in these parts of the world, which provides a lot of scope for us understand how these iants might influence our health.ldquoThere are some iants that are present in Glasgow, London, Edinburgh that we donrsquot find here, and we find others that are much, much more common here than where.ldquoBut we need to have sufficient samples of people with any given iant before we can make an inference about what that iant does, so itrsquos a very cost-effective way of looking otherwise very rare iants because they can actually be relatively common up here.ldquoMany of them will be doing absolutely nothing, but a subset of them will be medically important and increase risks of heart disease, cancer and other diseases.ldquoWe want to increase the number of people we have so that we can look into these iants more effectively.: Man banned from training as pilot over HIV finally takes to the skyThe team is not focusing on any one condition in particular, but some of their previous research has helped shed fresh light on puzzles such as why the populations of Orkney and Shetland have the worldrsquos highest rates of MS.ldquoMS has been a bit of a conundrum, said Prof Wilson. ldquoWe have shown that although vitamin D is important, itrsquos not the answer as to why therersquos such an excess in Orkney.ldquoBut common genetic iants donrsquot seem to be the answer either ndash so itrsquos likely itrsquos going to be down to even rarer genetic iants and yet again, we need more people to study rare things.Participants will be asked to complete an online questionnaire about their health and lestyle, and post a saliva sample which will be used to decode each inidualrsquos DNA.It is also the first time in the UK that a study has been given permission to feed medical data back to patients discovered to have so-called lsquoactionable iantsrsquo ndash genetic mutations known to cause or increase the risk of serious disease, but where action can be taken to prevent that.Prof Wilson said: ldquoThat could bethey had a high cholesterol iant,they had a BRCA gene for breast and oian cancer, and then there are a series of much rarer things that are important to know aboutyou have them.ldquoThings like LongQT syndrome ndash an inherited arrhythmia that you sometimes find among lads playing football who suddenly drop down dead. It increases the risk of sudden cardiac arrest during exercise.ldquoTypically around two per cent of people will have one of these actionable iants but in the past its not been possible to feed these back ndash wersquore the first study to get that permission.ldquoPeople can opt into it - they donrsquot have to do it.: Suicidal teens in care let down by lack of inpatient psychiatric bedsProf Wilson added that understanding genetics was the ldquofirst step to unpicking the mechanisms of disease so that better treatments can be developed in future.The study also involves Aberdeen University and NHS Grampian clinical genetics doctors Professor Zosia Miedzybrodzka and Dr John Dean, who have been holding clinics in Shetland and Orkney for over  years.Professor Miedzybrodzka said: ldquoBetter understanding the genetics of the Northern Isles will lead to better health care in the long run, both directly to the islanders but also worldwide.People who would like to take part can register their interest by visiting the study website: www.ed.ac.uk viking.

title: cobra-series-one-episode-one-review
story: Sky One and NOW TVHE has played Hitler, a stripper , and a Highland copper, so why shouldnrsquotRobert Carlyleplay a Tory Yet Begbie as a politician is not the most terrying notion in the new Sky One drama COBRA.Written by Ben Richards , COBRA imagines what would happena space storm hit Earth. That is the prospect facing Blighty as Conservative PM Robert Sutherland , his chief of staff Anna Marshall , and officials gather in Cabinet Office Briefing Room Ato hear from bearded men in cheap suits, otherwise known as scientists.Beard Number One says that in the first stage of a solar storm satellites will be knocked out, throwing navigation systems into flux. Planes could fall out of the sky. In the second stage, all electrical power will go off. No light, no heating, no internet, no Antiques Roadshow.Older readers will recognise this as the s. Back then, in the days of three-day weeks and power cuts, the populace lit candles, threw coats on the bed and got on with it. I suspect modern society, made of flimsier stuff, is not going to manage so well.Fortunately, Caryle is around to fulfil the Lance Corporal Jones role as chief calmer of the national panic. That is,he can spare the time, what with sneaky aides leaking his immigration plans to the press, his daughter landing in bother at university after a graduation party goes wrong, and keeping up that strange, Scots northern English accent he has adopted for the role.He also has to say COBRA a lot. The makers of COBRA are awfully fond of the word COBRA.ldquoConvene a full COBRA for the morning, barks Sutherland.ldquoThe CMErsquos trajectory is faster than anticipated, he tells his we.ldquoI donrsquot have a ******* clue what that means, she replies with some justication.ldquoIt means I have to reconvene COBRA!What is the betting ldquoconvening COBRA soon takes over from ldquobeing in Pizza Express, Woking as catchphrase of the year Everyone likes saying COBRA because it sounds dangerous, sexy, scary. It is the perfect title for a drama that is part political thriller, part disaster fest: House of Cards meets Jack Bauerrsquos , Bodyguard without the bare bahookies .Little expense has been spared in making everything look swish, from the high-tech briefing room, all very Mission: Impossible, to Annarsquos handsome London home and her buttery leather cross-body bag . In certain instances you might wish it was not so realistic .Some parts lack the same slick touch. There is the usual newspaper headline that would never make it into a real paper, the political types are cliches , and the dialogue is sometimes laughable for the wrong reasons, as when Anna tells her boss never to make jokes about gender because people ldquoliterally lose their s*** over it. Literally, really  That must be messy. And of course, everyone walks and talks really quickly, because that is the law for political dramas since The West Wing.No-one watches disaster thrillers for the dialogue. They are supposed to be cheesy and overblown. What we are here for is the ldquowhatand the spectacle, and COBRA looks like it will deliver on both fronts.Carlyle is such a first class actor you can really believe the boy from Maryhill could be a Tory. He and Hamilton make a convincing partnership, keeping the verbal sparks and witticisms flying, though it might have been more intriguingshe had been the PM and Carlyle her aide. Disaster dramas traditionally come along when society is in a state of flux and in need of reassurance - think of their heyday in the s. That COBRA should arrive now, just as Brexit is about to happen, is just coincidence, no As episode one ended, panic was spreading to France and Spain, Sutherland was activating the Civil Contingencies Act, and pressure was about to pile up on the government on several other fronts.ldquoThis is now an emergency, declared Sutherland, ldquoand COBRA will remain active to its conclusion.Who  you gonna call in the event of mass disaster but Begbie Available now on Sky One and NOW TV

title: shetland-dogs-turn-calendar-stars-become-charitys-best-friend
story: Now the Shetland canines are making charities paws for thought as the superstars in their very own sell-out calendar which has been winging its way around the world.Animal lover Kaylee Garrick has taught her seven dogs named, Fenton, Thiago, Thorin, Gimli, Murphy, Ghost and Jara some new modelling tricks - by becoming the stars of a special photoshoot in which they are posing in unusual costumes.Mrs Garrick, , an ambulance technician from Scalloway, Shetland who is also a keen photographer, snapped the pack donning kilts, wellies and sunglasses, for the calendar that is giving the original Calendar girls a run for their money.She captured them on camera on the shores of her island home and used autumn leaves and winter doggie jumpers to match the seasons.And the clever caninesrsquo calendar as been a sell-out success raising pound for good causes.Le in front of the camera is chicken feed for the six Shetland sheepdogs and Alaskan Klee Kai,who have been snapped at ious locations across Shetland in the past eight years. including the beach and historical monuments.Their snaps, which feature them often lined up in perfect unison and in costumes ndash have been used in the hospital in Shetland and on tourism websites promoting the area across the country. The canines are known to sit for y periods perfectly still, waiting for their next instructions.The photos of the pups have been used to calm patients, mainly children while they travel in an ambulance.They have even featured in a more intimate moment ndash Ms Garrickrsquos marriage to Robert in  at Bogbain Farm in Inverness.Last year they were used to launch a campaign to encourage more people to learn about basic le support training such as CPR.Ms Garrick even taught her dog Fenton to perform CPR and potentially save peoplersquos lives.The pooches were used in her campaign to catch peoplersquos attention, as well as strip back any fears people may have of learning CPR.Her Donrsquot Paws, Start CPR social media campaign featured an instructional video featuring her dog carrying out le-saving CPR on a mannequin.The cover for the calendar features her dogs arranging themselves into a heart shape and cuddled up close. Mrs Garrick added: ldquoThe response has been overwhelming, I could easily have sold double.We sold out extremely quickly with orders flying all over the world - USA, Canada, Finland, Sweden, Norway, Germany, France, Australia and New Zealand to mention a few places.She produced the calendar after repeated requests from her social media followers and said: ldquoOur photos usually feature quirky ideas, such as lining the streets wearing coloured sunglasses, relaxing in a field with butterfly wings, or looking tough dressed up as the Peaky Blinders.ldquoIf itrsquos got rainbows, makes you laugh and has seven or eight dogs in it, you can pretty much guarantee thatrsquos one of my photos.The calendar also features a Shetland word of the month so people from around the world can learn a little bit of the old Norse language.Mrs Garrick said: ldquo I have already had an American tourist come up to me with a grin on his face, telling me about his ldquopeerie toonie dug a term hersquod learned from his calendar.TASC, The Ambulance Staff Charity, which reaches out to anyone in the service who may need help, has received half of the cash raised, while the other half went to Bravehound, a charity that trains therapy dogs to help war veteransto le outside the forces.Mrs Garrick explained: ldquoTASC is a charity close to my heart, in working for the ambulance service you become part of a family.Our job can be pretty tough to say the least and once too many I have learned of a family member who wersquove lost to suicide - a death which may have been prevented had they received help from their ordeal.ldquoTASC aims to reach out to anyone in the service who may need help and hopefully prevent a hero from suffering in silence.ldquoBravehound is aimed at our war veterans who struggle to reinstate themselves back into normal le when theyhome.They do this by training therapy dogs to act as lelong companions for them.

title: pace-change-get-women-top-jobs-not-fast-enough
story: Engenderrsquos Sex and Power  study reports that this is the number of women it would take to be equal with men, who occupy  per cent of so-called ldquopower roles in Scotland.The study took into account a raft of industries including politics, the public sector, media, justice and business.However, the figures show an improvement on , which considered  women to be ldquomissing from top jobs.But, according to Engender, change is not coming quickly enough ndash and, while this yearrsquos report shows a rise, this represents only a marginal rise in some areas and backsliding in others.ldquoNot enough change is happening, the report claims, ldquoand not quickly enough, to redress the gender imbalance in Scotlandrsquos corridors of power.The report revealed a list of spheres that have less than % female representation.There are also no women chiefs at Scottish-based FTSE  and FTSE  companies and only two women out of the  people who head up top Scottish firms.And, in sport, only % of chief executives of Scotlandrsquos national governing bodies are female.ldquoWomenrsquos sport, the report said, ldquois categorically undervalued and marginalised in Scotland, resulting in a lack of visibility that has an impact on women and girlsrsquo activity.At present, only .% of Scotlandrsquos most senior office-holders in the judicial system are women, representing a decrease since  only two senior police officers are women and % of all police officer posts are held by men.ldquoGreater gender ersity, the report states, ldquois needed across Scotlandrsquos judiciary and police force to increase womenrsquos access to justice, and to tackle endemic violence against women.Emma Ritch, executive director of Engender said: ldquoSex And Power  shows that positions of power in Scotland are still overwhelmingly dominated by men ndash controlling decisions over legislation, convictions, the media we consume and the healthcare we receive.Three years has seen just % change in the overall representation of women in top positions, and several sectors, such as the judiciary, actually move backwards.One of the areas of greatest improvement is in politics. There, the report said, ldquoefforts by Scottish Government, action by political parties, and pressure from the general public has seen signicant gains. Half of Cabinet secretaries, the Scottish Parliament Corporate Body, and Scottish Members of the European Parliament are now women.However, the report described the pace of change of women being elected to local councils as ldquoglacial.Women still only account for % of councillors and % of council leaders. Equalities Minister Christina McKelvie said: ldquoIt is everyonersquos responsibility to address this gap.The Scottish Government has taken action to improve womenrsquos representation and to advance womenrsquos equality in a broad range of areas.In , we introduced the Gender Representation on Public Boards Act to improve the representation of women on listed public boards in Scotland. Women have the capacity to be great leaders and we need to make sure they are being given the opportunity.In media, the report notes ldquoScotland has only one woman as editor of a major national newspaper, one woman as political editor in a major newspaper [Dundee Courier editor Catriona MacInnes has retired] and one woman as head of a national broadcaster.Women in Journalism Scotland co-chairs Libby Brooks and Jan Patience said: ldquoAt a point when the political landscape has never been more fastchanging, and with the trial of a former first minister on multiple sexual assault charges imminent, it is crucial womenrsquos voices and perspectives are represented.

title: new-mps-twice-likely-private-education-constituents
story: New analysis for this newspaper shows six of the nationrsquos  seats fell to candidates who attended fee-paying schools, up from five in  and four in .The Scottish trend is the opposite of what is happening in England and Wales, where independently educated MPs are losing ground.However, those campaigning for Westminster to become more representative of the electorate say Scotland still does better than the rest of the UK for delivering a ldquostrong pipeline of state-educated politicians.Some  per cent of Scottish MPs went to private schools, according to The Herald research.That compares with an overall figure for the House of Commons of % which was calculated by the Sutton Trust, an educational equality charity.James Turner, its chief executive, said: ldquoThe December election may have led to several new faces among Scotlandrsquos representatives in Westminster, but their educational backgrounds remain relatively unchanged.ldquoWhile there is a small rise in the number of MPs educated at independent schools, Scottish MPs are only slightly more likely to have been to fee-paying schools than the general population.ldquoScottish MPs are much more representative of the electorate than MPs from the other nations, who are four times as likely to have been to an independent school than their constituents.ldquoTalented people from all backgrounds should have the opportunity to become MPs, and so it is important that Scotland continues to build a strong pipeline of state-educated politicians.Just over % of Scottish children go to fee-paying schools, according to the latest educational census.The Scottish cohort at Westminster is more ldquocomprehensive than their equivalents at Holyrood, where % are privately educated, a figure that has also risen over the years of devolution.The Herald has the schooling details of  out of Scotlandrsquos  MPs. One politician, Peter Grant of the SNP, declined to reveal details of his education, saying they were ldquonot relevant.MPs who spent at least some of their teenage years at a private secondary include Tory Alister Jack, the Scottish Secretary, who went to Glenalmond in Perthshire, and Liberal Democrat Jamie Stone, who spent some years at Gordonstoun, the Moray school attended by Prince Charles.At Westminster, the SNP is the party with the lowest proportion of privately educated MPs, less than % per cent, according to Herald numbers.The Sutton Trust ndash which has educational backgrounds for more than  MPs ndash put figures at % for Labour and % for the Tories.The Conservatives have changed in recent years. This election saw comprehensively-educated candidates take northern English seats.In Scotland there has been a similar pattern: only two of the  Tory incumbents were privately educated.One of those lost his seat in December. In fact, it was two SNP victories against the Tories that pushed up the privately-educated numbers in Scotland.Alyn Smith and John Nicolson, former pupils of fee-paying Hutchesonsrsquo Grammar in Glasgow, defeated one-time comprehensive candidates in Stirling and Ochil, and Perthshire South, respectively.Hutchesonsrsquo now has five politicians at a national level from its former pupils - the two MPs and three MSPs.No other school is so well represented.Two re-elected SNP MPs were also privately educated. QC Joanna Cherry attended St Margaretrsquos Convent school in Edinburgh, while Kirsty Blackman won a scholarship to Aberdeenrsquos Robert Gordonrsquos College.There are comprehensives that have multiple alumni in politics. Greenock Academy has two MPs ndash local boy Ronnie Cowan and the new LibDem member for North-east Fe, Wendy Chamberlain.So does Trinity High in nearby Renfrew, which is represented by the SNPrsquos Chris Stephens, of Glasgow South West, and Gavin Newlands, of Paisley and Renfrewshire North. Linlithgow Academy ndash alma mater of Alex Salmond ndash also continues its tradition of producing pro-independence politicians.It has more Scottish MPs than the Labour Party, including former Scottish Justice Secretary Kenny MacAskill, of East Lothian, and local MP Martyn Day.

story: IN the early th century there was a pulp magazine called Weird Tales that specialised in yarns with fantastical scenarios. The Diary has always viewed itself as a modern-day equivalent of that very mag, bringing you the best of the bizarre. As the world grows increasingly strange, it becomes more dficult for us to stand out from the crowd of crackpots and cranks scattered throughout the rest of your newspaper. This week, for instance, it was discovered that Gwyneth Paltrow was selling a certain candle with a most distinctive and, ahem, personal scent. title: sainsburys-named-cheapest-supermarket-uk-last-year
story: The consumer group has crowned the food store after tracking thousands of branded grocery prices across six major supermarkets throughout the year.And, according to their research, the top store is Sainsburys.Which  experts compiled a list of  common grocery itemsfrom Andrex toilet tissue to Weetabix breakfast cereal, and found that the goods cost just pound. a month at Sainsburyrsquos on average across the year.:Sainsburys closing more than  stores in major business overhaulIn stark contrast, the exact same items would have set you back pound. a month at Waitrose -  per cent more and potentially costing shoppers an annual total of pound. more thanthey had done the equivalent shopping at Sainsburyrsquos.Asda came in as the second cheapest supermarket, with an average monthly cost of pound. for the items on Which rsquos shopping list.Top six by priceSainsburys - pound.Asda - pound.Morrisons - pound.Tesco - pound.Ocado - pound.Waitrose - pound.Which  collected the data by monitoring online pricing, which means that only shops selling all of the branded items online ndash Asda, Morrisons, Ocado, Sainsburyrsquos, Tesco and Waitrose ndash have been included in the ranking. Morrisons followed closely behind in third place, charging pound..The likes of Aldi and Lidl continue to grow their market share in the UK, but neither offer an online shopping  for the branded items included in the Which  study.The consumer group ran a similar price comparison last year, and found that Morrisons was the cheapest supermarket of , followed by Asda and then Sainsburys.:Sainsburyrsquos sees sales tumble further amid lsquotoughrsquo supermarket environmentNatalie Hitchins, Which  Head of Home Products and Services, said: ldquoYour weekly supermarket shop can have a signicant impact on your wallet, and the start of a new year is a good time to look at your household spending to seethere are areas where you can save money.ldquoOur analysis shows how important it can be to shop around to ensure you get the best price for your groceries.

title: communities urged to take the plunge to celebrate year of coasts and waters
story: A new #, fund has been launched to help community groups celebrate Scotland#s Year of Coasts and Waters .Scottish Natural Heritageis marking the year with the launch of ‘Plunge In! The Coasts and Waters Community Fund’, offering a range of grants from small pots for schools and youth groups to awards of up to £,.Applications are now open for community-led ideas that will engage and connect more people with our seas, coasts, lochs, rivers, streams and wetlands, as well as their unique wildle.Projects might include plans for restoring habitats, carrying out surveys or promoting and celebrating theenvironment or wildle, and should leave a legacy from the year, for example through improved skills and knowledge or the creation of a community resource.Smaller grants of up to £ will also be available to allow groups of young people to connect with nature by visiting one of Scotland’s many stunning national or local nature reserves.Francesca Osowska, SNH chief executive, said: “As Scotland’s nature agency, we’re really excited about the Year of Coasts and Waters. “There is so much to celebrate about our coastlines and waterways and we want to encourage and inspire people to explore and enjoy them as much as possible throughout this year and beyond.“We know communities up and down the country will also want to celebrate the year in their own way, but we recognise that some might lack the resources to do so.“This new fund is a fantastic opportunity for groups to get involved, be creative, help their local environment and wildle and improve our coasts and waters.”Applications for Plunge In! title: citizens advice has been helping people in scotland since 1939
story: The first Citizens Advice Bureaux were set up  years ago, to help people during World War Two.Issues back then ranged from ration books to evacuations from homes and missing people.There are now  CABs theand breadth of the country, which are overseen by Citizens Advice Scotland .While the issues have evolved over the years, their remit has remained the same: to provide free, independent advice in complete confidence.Derek Mitchell, CAS chief executive officer, said: “We are the biggest independent provider of free advice in Scotland.“Our CABs offer a one-stop shop to help people solve their problems.“Someone can come in about their energy bills but we discover they have an average of seven dferent issues in their lives.“When you’re living on a budget and your washing machine breaks down, you have to make a choice to fix it and send your children to school with clean clothes or to pay your rent.“Making that choice can result in more debt.“That’s when our service really comes into its own.”And there’s little doubt that the advice service works CABs have dealt with , advice issues in the last year and helped more than , Scots.Last year, they secured £ million for the , people who made contact – money which has helped not only those seeking advice, but the communities in which they live.Derek said: “I think our trust rating speaks for itself:  per cent of people who have used our service would recommend us to a friend or relative.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.falkirkherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Hands-on...Superintendent Sharon Comriehas worked for the SSPCA for an incredible  years.
