title: Andrew blasts in four as United blitz Bangor YM
story: SAINTFIELD ed to action against Bangor Young Men in the Clarence Cup on Saturday and looked to bounce back after a disappointing loss last week.The Saints started well and scored the first goal in the th minute after a fluid counter-attacking move was finished by Andrew Clarke, who rled the ball into the roof of the net.Bangor applied the pressure for the next  minutes and were rewarded with an equalising goal. The Bangor attacker played in Kurtis Bell, who slotted the ball into the inside side-netting after Saintfield were dispossessed at the edge of their own box.Saintfield raised it a few gears and struck three times in the  minutes before half-time.The first came from Andrew Clarke after James Sofley was played down the line. After beating two defenders, James played in Andrew, who passed the ball into the bottom right-hand corner past the lsquokeeper.It took less than five minutes for left back Oliver Duff to score Saintfieldrsquos third. A long ball found Adam Childs on the left wing.He played it back to the edge of the box for Duff. He took one touch to set himself before striking a powerful left-footed shot into the bottom right corner.The Saints scored one more goal before the break with Andrew Clarke playing the ball across the face of goal for Tony Liken to finish at the back post. Saintfield went into half-time in the driving seat and - up.The second half started much like the first ended with Saintfield scoring an early goal.Ryan Sofley was the supplier of an own goal after bombing into the box and fizzing a cross into the near post which ricocheted off the Bangor defender into the net.At - up, the Saints took their foot off the gas and conceded just over five minutes after scoring.Bangor gained possession from a loose ball in midfield and played it into Matty Hall, who turned well to beat the Saintfield defender before striking the ball low and hard into the bottom corner.The Saints were again quick to respond with Andrew Clarke getting his hat-trick with half an hour still to go.Clarke started the move in midfield and finished it expertly after James Sofleyrsquos effort was parried by the lsquokeeper.Saintfield had a penalty and rebound saved less than two minutes later after James Sofley was brought down in the box.However, the Saints werenrsquot finished yet and Clarke had one more goal left in them with  minutes left to go. Possibly the best goal of the game, as he showed real determination and skill to score his fourth. Another counter-attacking goal from the Saints as they broke fast from a Bangor corner.Clarke received the ball just inside the Bangor half and stood tall after several attempts to bring him down. He beat three defenders before slotting home a cool finish into the bottom corner.This goal also signalled the end of the goalkeeperrsquos game after he strongly disagreed with the refereersquos decision to allow the goal to stand. Bangor had one more chance before the end of the game when they were also awarded a penalty, but David Harper kept the Saintsrsquo five-goal lead intact and made it a penalty saved for both teams.A great performance for Saintfield who progress to the next round of the cup and a fantastic performance from  year-old Andrew Clarke who relished his role as an attacking midfielder.Saintfield United Bangor Young Men CLARENCE CUP ND ROUND.prettyPhoto

title: Call to begin work on Ballynahinch bypass
story: THE re-establishment of the Stormont Executive has led to fresh calls for work to start on Ballynahinchrsquos proposed multi-million pound bypass.Newly appointed Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon is being urged to signal the start of construction work on the scheme which is estimated to cost in excess of poundm.South Down MP Chris Hazzard mdash a former roads minister in a previous Executive who signed off the eagerly-awaited bypass in December  mdash has written to Ms Mallon seeking an assurance that the Ballynahinch scheme remains a priority for her department and that construction work will start as soon as possible.In addition, Rowallane councillor Billy Walker is tabling a notice of motion at the February meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Council seeking across-the-board political support to seek an urgent meeting with Ms Mallon discuss the next step in the construction of the bypass.He also confirmed that Strangford MP, Jim Shannon, has written to Ms Mallon on the issue and is seeking a meeting with her to discuss the issue.There has been major progress on work on the near two-mile scheme to link the Newcastle and Saintfield roads, with work already completed on a major archaeological investigation along parts of the route.Work was due to complete on the schemersquos economic appraisal before the end of last year, with roads engineers confirming recently that in order to advance the bypass schemersquos state of readiness, preparatory work on contract documents was ongoing to ldquominimise the time required to initiate a procurement competition, should funding become available for construction.The by-pass, which would be the single biggest road scheme ever constructed in the district, is expected to take in excess of  months to build, with roads officials insisting that it will greatly benefit both strategic and local road users by reducing journey times and improving road safety.They are also confident that the schemersquos economic assessment demonstrates the by-pass would provide a good economic .The scheme is designed to alleviate chronic town centre congestion in Ballynahinch and along the main approach roads to the town.Major new roundabouts are proposed at the Belfast Road junction with the Saintfield Road and at the Newcastle Road junction with the Downpatrick Road, with a new bridge constructed over the Moss Road.It is also proposed that a section of the bypass will pass under part of the Crossgar Road with a  metre long bridge constructed to take traffic over Ballynahinch River.Overtaking lanes stretching almost  metres are proposed at either end of the bypass where major new roundabouts are to be constructed, with the scheme also including a shared footpath and cycle lane.Mr Hazzard said that following his decision to formally sign off the scheme at the end of , the government department had been working through ious legal stages to ensure the scheme could commence as soon as possible.ldquoA programme of geotechnical investigation works on lands along theof the scheme was completed in  with advanced archeological investigation works completed last year, he confirmed.ldquoThis allowed the Department to move ahead with the final stage of preparing contract documentation in readiness of funding becoming available to construct the scheme.Mr Hazzard added: ldquoWith an Infrastructure Minister now in place following the restoration of Stormont this week, funding should now be signed off and construction allowed to commence as soon as possible.Cllr Walker said it was the view of many, including senior roads engineers, that the multi-million pound scheme was vital to the survival of Ballynahinch town centre and will play a signicant role in helping boost the wider South Down economy.He said given that the project is shovel ready, it is essential that the cash is earmarked to allow construction work to start this year is forthcoming.ldquoMoving forward what is now required is the finance to build this scheme, continued Cllr Walker.ldquoIt is clear to me that when you look at other parts of Northern Ireland that Down District has consistently missed out on major roads funding. That must change and the cash needed to build Ballynahinchrsquos new bypass must be made available.The Rowallane councillor said that the bypass can help kick-start the economic regeneration of Ballynahinch town centre and act as a catalyst to encourage new investment.Cllr Walker added: ldquoThe eagerly-awaited scheme can address town centre gridlock and along the main approach roads. Ballynahinch is used as a gateway by visitors to Newcastle and the wider Mournes area in particular and we need to see work on the by-pass starting as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Charity ride helps African water plan
story: A PROJECT to provide African schoolchildren with clean drinking water is pound, better off thanks to the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride.Joan Cunningham, organiser of the annual festive event, recently presented a cheque to Pius Kulama, who works for I am Family Ministries in Uganda.Piusrsquos passion and dream is to help change the lives of everyone in the village and community where he was brought up.He explained the first thing needed was clean fresh water, for which a bore hole is vital. The bore hole will cost pound, and the Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride is committed to raising the necessary funds.Pius was a special guest at last monthrsquos charity ride and left a great impression on everyone he came into contact with.Pius lost both his parents to Aids when he was four years old and his little sister was just two.They were both looked after by the community in his village until he took very ill. Thanks to Rock Ministries, he was taken to the Ugandan capital, Kampala, where an operation saved his le.Aged , he was brought to Saintfield by Rock Ministries NI in  as a member of the Mawamba Choir, who delighted everyone in Saintfield with their singing and dancing and rode in the late George Fawcettrsquos carriages.With the help and sponsorship from I Am Family Ministries, Pius went on to university and achieved a Bachelor of Science degree in Quantitative Economics.Pius now works for I Am Family Ministries in Uganda and is also principal of a school for  orphaned and needy children in home village.A coffee morning to raise further funds for the bore hole appeal is being organised by Barbara Ennis, from Bright, in The Civic Centre, Downshire Estate, Downpatrick, on Thursday, February , from .am until  noon. Everyone is welcome.The  Saintfield Christmas Charity Ride will take place on Saturday, December ..prettyPhoto

title: Daniel joins BMW Juniors
story: ANNAHILT teenager Daniel Harper is set for an exciting new chapter in his burgeoning career after being signed as a member of the new BMW Junior Team for the next two seasons, which will see him make his international racing debut as a manufacturer-backed driver.Following his sensational recent spell competing in the UK, Harper has been hand-picked by one of the biggest and most successful manufacturers in global motorsport to be part of their exclusive young driver development programme. will mark a comeback for the prestigious BMW Junior Team name. It was launched in  and made headlines as the first factory team in German racing to field a team made up solely of young drivers, and BMWrsquos commitment to nurturing talent has continued ever since.Harper will be embarking on a ldquoholistic, first-class, intensive development programme across the next two seasons, with fitness and mental training camps at Formula Medicine as well as team building through the three BMW Junior Team drivers living together in shared accommodation.On-track, a comprehensive race training programme will take place at the iconic Nuumlrburgring-Nordschlee circuit. In , Harper will complete the entire season of the VLN Endurance Series and the prestigious  Hours of Nuumlrburgring event.As part of the programme, Harper will receive mentorship from Jochen Neerpasch..prettyPhoto

title: Delay to £3m Lidl proposal
story: A RECOMMENDATION to approve a new poundm Lidl store in Newcastle has been deferred by Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee.The decision to defer the plannersrsquo recommendation was taken at last weekrsquos committee meeting in Newry after a late submission was received.The supermarket giant is seeking permission for the new store at the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site.The development proposal also includes a new pound, base for the Mourne Mountain Rescue Team at the . acre Shanslieve Drive site in the resort, with entry to the proposed store via Bryansford Road.Plans to redevelop the former primary school site were originally submitted in January  with permission being sought to bulldoze the existing school to pave the way for the construction of a new food store and the dedicated centre for the volunteers who run the mountain rescue team. Lidl, which currently employs  staff, claims its proposal will create  new jobs.In late November, the local council confirmed that outline permission granted in March for the multi-million pound development was to be quashed as a result of a judicial review brought by developer Don Holdings Ltd.However, days later, the agenda for the December meeting of the Planning Committee included a plannersrsquo recommendation to approve the new store proposal. The recommendation was subsequently withdrawn, but features on the agenda for todayrsquos meeting with a recommendation to approve.The Newcastle development proposal includes plans for almost  parking spaces, eight of which are reserved for mountain rescue team members.A new pedestrian crossing at the Bryansford Road junction with Shimna Road forms part of the proposal, with planners receiving  objections. Five five letters in support of the new rescue team base proposal have also been lodged.Lidl has consistently argued that its current base at Railway Street in Newcastle is too small to allow the store to carry the companyrsquos full range of goods, highlighting issues with narrow aisles and inadequate parking provision.It says the Railway Street base was only supposed to be a temporary home until a larger unit could be found.Lidl says it has been looking for an alternative town centre site for over decade without success until the Shanslieve Drive site became available, with the planned mountain rescue team centre providing the volunteers with a permanent base.Objectors to the new store proposal claim that there are ldquoserious errors in the transport assessment submitted in conjunction with the planning application, inaccurate land ownership information, unachievable visibility spays and out-of-season traffic surveys.A Newry, Mourne and Down Council spokeswoman confirmed yesterday that the Lidl planning application was deferred to allow further consideration of a number of submissions received by the local authority.She added: ldquoThe Council is endeavouring to bring this application back to the Planning Committee in Februarypossible..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C January 15%2C 1980
story: BALLYNAHINCH mdash Police believe that a professional gang were behind the drugs raid on a Ballynahinch chemist shop at the weekend.The thieves smashed their way into Hannawinrsquos Medical Hall in Main Street through a skylight and forced open a door to get to the shop. They used a crowbar to prise the steel cabinet containing a store of dangerous drugs out of the wall. The cabinet was later found along the side of the Carrickmannon Road, near Ballygowan.The drugs taken included heroin and cocaine, both of which are dangerous even in small doses. They are types of hard drug in big demand on the black market. Additives like glucose are used by drug pushers to multiply the volume and increase profits. Other drugs, including morphine and strychnine, were also taken.The raid was the latest in a spate across the province and police fear that the addiction problem could be more serious than previously realised.Police chiefs have backed chemists pressing for an urgent review of the Home Office regulations about the keeping of prescribed drugs in steel cabinets.The present procedure is making things too easy for the thieves. It has meant that the hard drugs are all kept in the same place and the professional thief knows that.Before  regulations, chemists had better safeguards, evenit meant hiding the hard drugs on the general drugs shelves. It meant that thieves could not go straight to the security cabinet and other break it open or take it with them.The head of the RUCrsquos drugs squad, Chief Inspective George McBride, said he agreed that there was an urgent need to re-examine safety procedures for storage of dangerous drugs.DOWNPATRICK mdash Compensation for the destruction of St Patrickrsquos Hall in Downpatrick has been agreed mdash almost six years after it was destroyed by fire.The trustees of St Patrickrsquos Parish were awarded pound, at Downpatrick Crown Court last Friday after a two-hour hearing.The award was made in four parts, the bulkbeing attributable to physical damage and the remainder split between loss of profits , contentsand site value pound,.The claim had been before the court for over a year and was held up after the Northern Ireland Office disputed the amount of the parishrsquos claim for loss of profits.On Friday counsel for the Northern Ireland Office argued that the hall trustees had not made a big enough effort to reduce lost profits. But this was strongly refuted by counsel for the hall trustees.In a -minute summing up, the judge looked at the ious points of the case. He said he felt the church had not acted unreasonably and that the trustees had done everything required of them under law.STRANGFORD mdash A Strangford schoolboy will pack his bags later this year to take up a scholarship at a new college at Cambridge mdash with the long term prospects of becoming a Cambridge don.He is  year-old Andrew McDowell, who is an A Level student at Down High School, and he learned this week that he was won an open exhibition to the famed university.In academic terms he has won the equivalent of a junior scholarship and he will be among the first major intake at the new Robinson College.Andrew already has nine O Levels and he sat the examination in November along with several thousand others.In October he will pack his bags to concentrate on Mathematics at the college, with the scholarship being renewable after two years. His success is all the more remarkable because he is a year younger than most other candidates.Andrew is studying A Level Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry at Down High. His father is Mr Alan McDowell, principal of Portaferry Primary School.CASTLEWELLAN mdash A  year-old Castlewellan woman was awarded pound, compensation for the loss of both legs in a bomb blast three years ago at Belfast Recorders Court last week.She is Miss Monica McCavera, who had been a chief buyer for a leading Dublin fashion store at the time of the explosion.Miss McCavera, who had been visiting her family in Castlewellan, received her injuries when she was on a shopping trip to Belfast. The no-warning bomb exploded in Joy Street and as a consequence she lost both her legs.ARDGLASS mdash Ardglass Castle, known locally as Kingrsquos Castle, has recently been sold, a spokesman for estate agency firm Osborne King and Megran has confirmed.The sum involved and the new owners are not disclosed, but it is understood the th century, -bedroom castle will be turned into a hotel and restaurant.The previous owners, Sean Tracey and his we Bernadette, had planned to make the castle into a hotel and had obtained planning permission, but they have recently transferred their interest to another establishment.Little is known about the history of the building, other than Percy French, the well-known Irish composer and painter, stayed there. Several of Frenchrsquos best views across Ardglass harbour are said to have been painted from the castle.NEWCASTLE mdash People suffering from acute and chronic diseases can now be treated at a unique new clinic in Newcastle.The Shimna Valley Clinic, which was opened yesterday, has been established to treat the sick with the most advances therapies available in the field of natural therapeutics. It is being jointly sponsored by osteopath Mr Robin Boyd and a former patient, Mr Ronnie Herron.ldquoPatients will only be accepted , in the judgement of the consultant, Mr Boyd, there is a high degree of certainty that improvement or cure is possible, said Mr Herron.ldquoOsteopathy, homeopathy, herbal naturopathy and dietic control will be used. The emphasis at Shimna Valley will be on peace and tranquility. There is no hospital atmosphere, he added.SPA mdash Spa Young Farmersrsquo Clubrsquos first meeting of the New Year was the annual lsquoExchange Talkrsquo and club member John Knipe filled the role admirably by giving an account of his travels to Canada last year as part of Northern Irelandrsquos representation in a three-month exchange visit.John travelled to Canada in June, being one of two representatives from the province, and he gave an interesting and amusing talk on his visit, accompanied by some interesting slides.KILLINCHY mdash Killinchy Young Farmersrsquo Club figured well in the group debating competition held in Knockbreda High School.The - year-old group team of Johnston Morrow, David Hanna and Sharon White came first, while in the same age grop the other Killinchy team of Peter Morrow, David Robinson and Kevin Howell came second.In the - years age group, the team of Yvonne Magowan, Katherine Kelly and Florence Armstrong finished runners-up and the team competing in the - age group, Laura Robinson, Jacqueline Kelly and David Martin, came second.The winning team now goes forward to the NI final in March. The club would like to thank Mr Addy Morrow and Mr Robin Morrow, who coached the teams so successfully.SHEEP mdash An outbreak of sheep scab has been confirmed in the Downpatrick area by the Department of Agriculture.The outbreak occurred earlier this month and the Department report that infected sheep have been wandering on roads and lands in the area.However, officials stress that known infected sheep have been dipped and the tracing of flocks which have been in contracted with the infected animals is continuing.This week the Department issued an appeal to anyone seeing sheep showing the symptoms to report details to the local isional veterinary office immediately. ldquoWe are not satisfied that all diseased sheep have been traced, a spokesman added..prettyPhoto

title: Gabriel gets recogition as top Mathematics student
story: NEWCASTLE student Gabriel Corrigan is officially a whizz at Mathematics after gained the highest A Level marks in the subject in Northern Ireland.The  year-old is a former student of Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle and is now studying Mathematics at Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge.He recently ed home to attend the examination board CCEArsquos recognition event at the Titanic Centre in Belfast to receive an award for his achievement.Gabrielrsquos success follows on from another Shimna student, Mia Pobloth, who came joint top in Northern Ireland in GCSE German last year.Shimna principal Kevin Lambe said: ldquoThis year we are delighted to celebrate with Gabriel, as we celebrated last year with Mia. What makes us particularly pleased with Gabrielrsquos success is that he has been such a pleasure to teach, and has made an outstanding contribution to Shimna and to our Integrated ethos in so many ways.ldquoI was reminded of a very young Gabriel addressing a gathering of Integrated school principals when he was only in Year , impressing them then with his commitment.Mr Lambe said that Gabriel was also ldquoproud to be a past pupil of All Childrenrsquos Integrated Primary School in Newcastle.He added: ldquoWe wish him every future success and happiness..prettyPhoto

title: How a Ballynahinch church pioneered social welfare scheme
story: THE provision of welfare in Ballynahinch  years ago will come under the spotlight at a meeting of the Lecale and Down Historical Society in Down County Museum, Downpatrick, next Monday evening, January .Local historian Horace Reid will reveal how the townrsquos First Presbyterian Church organised a social scheme long before the Welfare State came into being.There were a number of charity schemes in Co Down at the time, aimed at alleviating poverty, and also at curbing rogue beggars. The Ballynahinch venture was unique in having a large amount of surviving documentation.Mr Reid says it is clear from these papers that the scheme organised by the First Presbyterian Church was sophisticated, comprehensive, self-funded, and cradle-to-grave in scope. It included widowsrsquo and old age pensions, end of le and burial grants, and support for orphans.Finance allocated to the project was known as lsquoThe Poorrsquos Moneyrsquo. The scheme operated late in the reign of William III and was continued into the time of Queen Anne, George I and George II.Nowadays benefit claimants unable to work through illness or injury, are paid Employment Support Allowance, .In  a similar scheme was obviously operating in Ballynahinch. The church carpenter at that time was John Gough, and that year he suffered a signicant injury, perhaps a broken arm or leg. He was unable to work or to earn a living for over a year.John had been married six years earlier in , in his home congregation by Rev James McAlpine. His we was Elizabeth, neacutee Ferguson. Their children soon followed mdash Christine, who was five in  Rebecca, who was four, and their twin boys, George and James, who were just one year and one month.With four young children and no income, John and Elizabeth were soon struggling financially. But in April the church stepped in immediately, with payments for an initial three-month period, at six shillings per instalment. In August John tried to resume work, but couldnrsquot. The church continued payments, but now at a reduced rate of d. Another attempt at work in October  failed again, and again payments resumed.John eventually recovered and ed to work permanently in August , having received a total of  support payments from First Presbyterian. He resumed his valuable role in maintenance of the fabric, receiving church contracts in ,  and .The problem of unwed mothers and absent fathers is one that troubles every age and every generation. Back in the early s, the Ballynahinch Session took a stern approach to fire-and-forget fatherhood.Their starting point was an interview with the expectant mother to ascertain the identity of her co-responsible male partner. If she proved uncompliant, exclusion from church attendance was then threatened. Faced with resultant near-total social ostracism, the mother-to-be soon cooperated.The next stage involved the errant couple appearing some Sunday morning before the entire congregation, kneeling on the Stool of Repentance and confessing their extramarital transgression. After that they were received back into the congregation. Their child was baptised and recognised as a church member.In a -year period the Ballynahinch Session dealt with  such cases. In six, they identied both parents. In six other cases only the mother was identied in seven, only the father. In one case the origins and surname of a lsquofoundlingrsquo child were known, but neither parent actually came forward.By st century standards, these church procedures sound draconian. But they had the purpose of protecting the rights of the child and of offering an opportunity to the parents for their reputations to be salvaged,possible.The alternatives were a lot worse. It was common in the s for the sexton at Magheradroll Parish Church to discover live newborns abandoned overnight on his church doorstep, ordead through neglect or infanticide, to find their bodies surreptitiously concealed in adjacent graves.In Ireland such surviving infants were sent in large numbers to the Foundling Hospital in Dublin, which who received between ,-, orphans annually. The hospitalrsquos mortality rate was some %.In Ballynahinch, under Presbyterian auspices, some such infants were spared this grisly fate. The lives of a number of potential orphans were actively protected by the church in their home town.Under the Welfare Reform Act of , Disabled Living Allowance was controversially replaced with Personal Independence Payment. DLA payments were made to claimants who often had long term medical conditions. The amount of the award ied according to the degree of disability.Interestingly, in Ballynahinch in the early s, First Presbyterian made a number of long-term DLA-type awards to some lsquosupplicantsrsquo.Ms Grissel Foreman was on such a benefit from -. Some financial records of the Poorrsquos Money still exist. But all its other documentation is lost, so we donrsquot know what Grisselrsquos ailment actually was. It was obviously slow and progressive, perhaps something like tuberculosis, or multiple sclerosis, or Parkinsonrsquos.As her condition deteriorated, the church increased its amount of financial support. In  she received seven payments totalling s d. By  this had escalated to  payments totalling pound s d.She died in  and was buried at church expense. Over  years, amounts paid to her totalled pound s d. This was an enormous sum, considering the church ministerrsquos annual stipend at the time was pound.These and many other such stories will be outlined on Monday night at Down Museum. Mr Reidrsquos talk begins at .pm. Admission is pound for non-members of the historical society..prettyPhoto

title: in sessions to discuss town centre development plans
story: RATEPAYERS are being asked to help shape a special study being undertaken by Newry, Mourne and Down Council on the districtrsquos retail and commercial leisure needs over the next decade.The study will examine the need for additional floorspace and consider how the local authorityrsquos future planning polices for retail and commercial use could assist in sustaining the vitality and viability of town centres.The information contained in the new study will be used to help formulate the districtrsquos new local development plan.A series of so-called -in sessions are being held this week in Ballynahinch, Saintfield, Newcastle and Downpatrick to provide people with an opportunity to review initial findings by consultants and to provide comment ahead of the formal publication of the study.Downpatrick area councillor, Dermot Curran, said it is essential that the local authority does all it can to grow the districtrsquos economy.He said that moving forward, the focus must be on job creation and helping deliver economic regeneration to benefit existing traders and businesses keen on investing in the area.Cllr Curran said it was important that the council works on building key relationships with the business community, from small independent traders upwards to see what assistance they can be provided with to ensure they remain at the heart of the districtrsquos economy.He said he was keen to see the detail of the retail and commercial leisure need study, in particular, the levels of expenditure in the districtrsquos towns and villages.He also said it was important that the local authority supports and works alongside businesses which provide employment.ldquoIt is important to be at the forefront of supporting the districtrsquos business community, he continued. ldquoThere is not point waiting for new economic opportunities to arise. We must go out there and grab them by selling what the district has to offer.Cllr Curran said given that the Newry, Mourne and Down area is the third largest of the provincersquos  district councils, it should be an ldquoattractive proposition for potential investors.ldquoThe focus moving forward must be on new job creation in both the public and private sector. It is important that we sell what the area has to offer.In relation to public sector job opportunities, Cllr Curran said available space at the Downshire Civic Centre could be utilised by a number of government departments keen to decentralise their operations from the greater Belfast area.He continued: ldquoNew investment will not happen out of the blue. We all have a duty to work together to secure it. I believe we need new hotels and there is a need for such a facility in the Downpatrick area and hope see progress on this issue in the near future.Cllr Curran is particularly keen to see the proposed commercial development at the site of the former Irish Street police station in Downpatrick and a number of adjacent derelict buildings progressed this year.ldquoThis exciting proposal has the potential to restore Downpatrickrsquos economic heart, create jobs and, most importantly, provide a boost for existing businesses via increased footfall, he said.Cllr Curran also warned that while attracting new investment is crucial, cracking Downpatrickrsquos traffic congestion problem is also essential.ldquoGridlock continues to stle town centre investment and we need to act quickly. While expensive schemes have been proposed in the past, nothing has happened. We must see progress in  and ensure roads officials deliver.ldquoWork was completed recently on a major upgrade of the Collinsrsquo Corner junction and while welcome, I and others remain to be convinced that it will address congestion problems in the heart of the town.Cllr Curran said roads officials also deserve praise for the improvement scheme in Fountain Street and hopes that in  efforts will be made by the Department for Infrastructure to improve Edward Street.He added: ldquoThis is a real problem area which has not been addressed. The presence of a busy primary school should ensure that roads officials redouble their efforts to improve driver and pedestrian safety. In addition, urgent action is needed to ban large vehicles, especially lorries, from this built-up area..prettyPhoto

title: Looking back at end of steam railways
story: SEVENTY years ago today, the first part of Northern Irelandrsquos railway network literally came to the end of the line, with the axe falling on a large part of the old Belfast and County Down Railway, marking the end of  years of railway transport in East Down.On January , , railway stations south of Comber fell quiet and an eerie silence descended upon mile after mile of what had once been a key transport corridor.No longer would the rumble of trains and passenger-filled carriages pass through on their way to Castlewellan or Newcastle, stopping at Ballygowan, Saintfield, Ballynahinch junction, Crossgar, or Dundrum on the way, or perhaps branching off after Downpatrick for Ardglass.Later, on April , , services from Belfast to Comber - with stops at Bloomfield, Neillrsquos Hill, Knock, Dundonald and on to Donaghadee also ceased.Robert Gardiner, chairman of the Downpatrick and County Down Railway, a heritage railway set up on the former Downpatrick BCDR terminus, states that had the line survived to today, it would form a vital transport link between the commuter belt into the Northern Irish capital.ldquoIt seems incredible today to think that such a vital transport link could be easily discarded, he says. ldquoBut in  the ministers in the devolved Stormont Government took the view that railways were as obsolete as the stagecoach.ldquoIn a way, they were right that the lines were Edwardian relics mdash and the BCDR in particular still operated obsolete Victorian carriages mdash but investment since then in new technologies in track, signalling and rolling stock have shown what we could have had throughout Northern Ireland.ldquoBut even then, in  an express train from Comber to Belfast could get you into the old Queenrsquos Quay station near the Odyssey area in  minutes ndash despite the investment in the Glider and other public transport initiatives nothing has come close to replicating that speed and efficiency.Up to the s, the main railway network in Northern Ireland was operated by three major railway companies mdash the London Midland and Scottish Railwayrsquos Northern Counties lines, which operated out of York Road Station to Larne and Londonderry the Great Northern Railway of Ireland, which operated out of Great Victoria Street Station to places like Dungannon, Armagh, as well as Dublin and the Belfast and County Down Railway, based at Queenrsquos Quay Station.In , the Stormont government decided to nationalise the network and amalgamate the LMS and BCDR with the bus operator, the Northern Ireland Road Transport Board, to form the Ulster Transport Authority, a predecessor to Translink.Mr Gardiner explains, ldquoA tribunal was set up to consider how this could be best achieved and provide an integrated transport system. Rail chiefs, who had been hoping for investment after the railways had proved so crucial to the war effort a few years earlier and that the buses would be barred from competing with the trains and instead provide a feeder service to stations, were devastated at the outcome.ldquoThe recommendation, accepted by Stormont, was that the entire Belfast and County Down Railway main line from Belfast to Newcastle, including the branches to Donaghadee, Ballynahinch and Ardglass, should be closed.The only route to be saved was the Belfast to Bangor connection, which continues operating successfully to this day.Mr Gardiner continued: ldquoThe attitude of Stormont was that it would be cheaper to move everything to the roads than to invest in railways that had been run down during the Second World War. People would use the buses instead. They developed huge road building schemes mdash most were never completed mdash but closed the railways first before these were even started. It seems incredible today.ldquoThe most puzzling element of the decision was the axing of the Belfast to Newtownards line, which served the east of the city mdash Dundonald, Knock and Comber areas in which the suburbs were developing and likely to provide increased commuter traffic had they been spared.ldquoIndeed, there were more than enough new diesel trains ordered to operate both the Bangor and Newtownards lines mdash and evidence suggests that the Transport Tribunal expected Stormont to spare the Comber line as a compromise option and as late as , before the tracks were lted, they were calling on the minister responsible to reverse the decision and trial these new diesel trains on this section of track mdash a call that fell on deaf ears.The  closures were the first steps in a plan which was to see the reduction of the Northern Irelandrsquos railway network from  miles to  miles mdash a decrease of  per cent.A decade later, the Great Northern Railway was ided between the UTA and its counterpart in the Republic, CIE, and further closures to lines to Armagh, Dungannon, Omagh and Strabane occurred.Willie Watterson and James Magill, who were porters and ticket clerks at Newcastle and Tullymurry stations, recalled their memories of the last train in an interview recorded for the BBC documentary lsquoRaising Steamrsquo in ldquoThe last train was a Sunday night. It was a cold winter night, January , , said Willie. There was twelve coaches, and two engines and two guards. She was packed. Packed to the doors. So I lit all the lamps, and put detonators on the line to give her a send-off.James added: ldquoI think every station did the same thing, so when the train came in there was a salute of bangs. I felt terrible about it, terribly terribly sad. I still felt it couldnrsquot happen. Still felt theyrsquoll come back, theyrsquoll run again. I couldnrsquot believe therersquod be no more railways, after working on them so hard.Adam Hamilton, who was a fireman mdash the person who stoked the fire on the steam locomotives mdash said: ldquoIt broke my heart, because the railways were in my blood. I still hear the sound of the steam still running on a clear night puffing away.Today, the Downpatrick and County Down Railway keeps the memory alive through its reconstruction of two miles of the former main line, as well as restored carriages rescued from their fate as hen houses.As part of its commemorations of the BCDRrsquos demise, it is keen to make contact with anyone who had any connection with the network, including former employees or their families, or people in possession of railway memorabilia such as photographs, tickets, timetables or even carriages.Mr Gardiner added: ldquoOne thing we would love for the museum is a BCDR unorm or tunic. So far we have been unable to track one down. Perhaps you have something in your loft And what of the future of the line  In November  the section of the BCDRrsquos former main line from Holywood Arches to Comber was opened as the Comber Greenway, whilst other sections have been used for roads as well as the section around Downpatrick being used by the DCDR.In the early s Northern Ireland Railways prepared a feasibility study into reopening the line to Newtownards, but this was not taken further by the Direct Rule administration.In May , the Department for Regional Development published its Railway Investment Prioritisation Strategy, which promised feasibility studies into the reopening of closed railway routes to Armagh, Dungannon and Castledawson by , but not including the Comber Newtownards route.However, maybe  years after the first railway closure in Northern Ireland, the new Minister for Infrastructure in the restored Stormont Government might see the first of those historic mistakes rectied.The Downpatrick Railway Museum can be contacted via email at info@downrail or message at www.facebook downrail..prettyPhoto

title: Mickey ‘magic’ to help Magpies lift cup
story: KILCOOrsquoS tearaways may hold the key to success in Sundayrsquos All-Ireland Club SFC final at Croke Park.The ability of their six forwards to win dirty ball and turnovers could dismantle the perceived invincibility of Corofinrsquos much-vaunted defensive system.Corofin, described in many quarters as the best club team ever, have an enviable set of defenders who squeeze the le out of the opposition.However, they have never encountered a team like Kilcoo before that has  attackers and  defenders.Conor Laverty, the three Johnston brothers mdash Ryan, Jerome and Shealan mdash Paul Devlin and Ryan McEvoy fight tooth and nail for every ball.They are the clubrsquos first line of defence and are not afraid to go where angels fear to tread, but can then turn into a snatch squad with the blink of an eye.Kilcoo will have to be at their bestthey are to cause an upset as the Galway and Connacht champions are sizzling hot favourites at   to win the Andy Merrigan Cup for an unprecedented third year in a row and the fourth time in six years.Certainly, Kilcoo have it all to do, but they fear no side.Manager Mickey Moran has twice taken Slaughtneil to All-Ireland finals day and few would begrudge the Derry man a first title with Kilcoo.He has transformed the Magpies into a ruthless, disciplined machine in a quiet, unobtrusive way and has won many admirers for his style of play.He started out in management in  when he took over the reins at Derry, the first of three separate spells in charge of the county team. He was also part of Eamon Colemanrsquos team that famously won the Sam Maguire Cup in .Dferent spells at Sligo and Leitrim followed before he masterminded Mayorsquos journey to the All-Ireland final in , but they lost out to Kerry.Taking Slaughtneil to two All-Ireland club finals followed before he assumed control of the Magpies last year and the rest is history.The much-loved Moran has the complete backing of every single one of the  players in the  and selector and coach Conleith Gilligan, who is also a former Derry player, believes Moran has the Midas touch.ldquoHis record speaks for itself and has the players eating out of the palm of his hands mdash they would do anything for him, he revealed at the clubrsquos press night last Thursday.ldquoI just canrsquot put it into words what Mickey has about him. Maybe its just a bit of magic dust, but itrsquos definitely a unique ability to get players to play for him.ldquoIt doesnrsquot matter what age you are. If you are good enough, he will give you a chance, he added.ldquoDonrsquot forget we won the Ulster League last season with five or six minors starting regularly every week.ldquoThat injection of youth sure helped the lads get a great start to the season and everything fell into place after that, he continued.Gilligan also believes that Moranrsquos love for the game and the way it should be played has rubbed off on the players.ldquoMickey is extremely keen on discipline. He insists the players play the game and let the referee do his thing without being shouted at.ldquoHe doesnrsquot rant or rave from the sidelines and expects that same response from the players and gets it, he added.Dedication and team structure are what he has instilled at Eoghan Rua Parc and a love for the game along with a winning environment.Kilcoo have been the benchmark in Down football for the past decade, but Moran has taken them a stage further in just  months.Corofin may be blessed with several players who have turned out regularly for Galway and in Kieran Fitzgerald, Liam Silke, Kieran McGrath, Gary Sice and Ian and Daithi Burke they have the nucleus of a talented outfit.However, Kilcoo believe they bigger they are, the harder they fall..prettyPhoto

title: Minister vows to end strikes with pay deal
story: HEALTH staff across the district were yesterday digesting the news that new Stormont Health Minister Robin Swann had confirmed that pay parity with their colleagues in England can now be restored.He told the Assembly that it would cost an extra poundm that would come from within existing Stormont finances.Mr Swann met with representatives from a number of leading health trade unions to brief them on the decision, describing the talks as ldquoconstructive.The new man in charge of the Provincersquos health portfolio said the ldquobreakthrough that we all wanted has been achieved this isa good day after some very dficult days.Mr Swann announced that the Department of Health had already gathered together poundm to increase pay for health workers, with an extra poundm being pulled from existing finances at Stormont.His decision to address the pay issue came after a series of strikes involving staff across the health and social services sector over pay and staffing levels.Nurses and other health workers in Northern Ireland have been taking industrial action over pay and staffing levels, with Mr Swann confirming that his officials would work with the unions on the issue of safe staffing levels in the health service and hopes a plan can be drawn up to establish such levels ldquowithin a reasonable period of time.Today, representatives from trade unions representing nurses and all health and social services staff will meet with Department of Health officials, with Mr Swann hoping for a ldquoswt end to their industrial action.He added: ldquoOur nurses and great social care workers can come off the picket-line.Prior to yesterdayrsquos announcement, local nurses said that they hoped that theof Stormont would pave the way for the pay parity and staffing issues to be finally addressed.Ahead of yesterdayrsquos meeting, the RCN said while welcoming the restoration of the Stormont administration, nurses had been made many promises.The RCNrsquos Northern Ireland Director, Pat Cullen, said nurses wanted to see those promises converted into action.Last Wednesday and Friday, nurses based at the Downpatrick hospitals took part in the latest round of stoppages and were buoyed by the support of passing motorists and others as they manned the picket-line at the entrance to the Downshire Civic Centre.Braving bitterly cold conditions last Friday morning, nurses were hoping for positive news from Stormont, hours after Secretary of State Julian Smith and Irish Foreign Affairs Minister Simon Coveney had published the New Decade New Approach document.Nurses, who had sacriced another dayrsquos pay, were joined at one stage on the picket-line by South Eastern Trust interim chief executive Seamus McGoran and Roisin Coulter, the organisationrsquos director of planning.Nurses said that they hoped that the political parties would go back into government and that their demands for pay parity and safe staffing levels would be met.ldquoWe believe that the collective pressure of health service staff has ensured that politicians know that they must get back to Stormont, said nurse Irene Murray.ldquoWe do not want to be used as political pawns and hope that there is cross-party agreement for politicians to get back to work. While pay parity and safe services are key issues for us, the key thing is that there are enough recurrent resources in place to deliver this now and in the future.Irene said the RCN is about putting patients first, describing the scale of the hospital waiting list issue as ldquounacceptable.She added: ldquoEmploying more nurses can help bring waiting lists down. This is not a new phenomena. It is tough to work as a nurse and it is not an easy job. But we currently have a situation where some nurses are taking on extra shts to earn more money, but that is just an unacceptable way to live.Alison Megarry said patients are nursesrsquo primary concern and at the heart of what they do, highlighting the need to keep staff working in Northern Ireland to ensure they donrsquot go across the water and donrsquot come back.She revealed that she was talking to a nursing sister last week who was working on international recruitment for nurses in Mumbai to work in Northern Ireland.ldquoThe nurses in India said why would they come here when the pay is less than it is in England, Scotland and Wales. I believe thatwe can keep our nurses here, it will help to tackle the waiting list issue, she said. ldquoThe big issue we have is that the population is ageing and people are living longer which therefore impacts on waiting lists.Nurse Sonia McCoubrey said that while pay parity is one issue, additional nurses are also required. She said many newly qualied nurses are choosing to go to England, Scotland or Wales because the money is better.She also said she worries about the safety of newly qualied nurses managing dficult situations and the patients they are caring for.ldquoYou have trolley waits and people lying in corridors. There is no privacy, no dignity and the situation is appalling. You go home at night after a sht burnt out and worried about what you have seen, the nurse added.Nurse Donna Boyd also expressed concern about waiting lists and said she fears that the situation is going to get worse, forcing many people to go private.ldquoIf more money is put into the system nurses are quite happy to do even more to help reduce waiting lists. All nurses go and above what is required of them when they are working, often staying after their scheduled quitting time which is unpaid work, she said.ldquoWith more people going private because of y waiting lists, a lot of the doctors and consultants are taking on private lists which then impacts on the NHS list. I have friends who were nurses who have left the profession to work in supermarkets because they have burnt themselves out. They canrsquot cope with the demands being made on them, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Now is the time for delivery – McGrath
story: THE restoration of the Assembly and Northern Ireland Executive should herald delivery for people at the start of a new decade, according to South Down SDLP MLA Colin McGrath.Mr McGrath was able to take his seat in the Assembly chamber for the first time in three years last Saturday, an occasion which he described as a ldquomomentous day for Northern Ireland and its future.He said that with so many issues staring people in the face including Brexit, y hospital waiting times, workersrsquo rights and wages, welfare issues and an education system in crisis, Northern Ireland needed a restored and fully ing Assembly and Executive to deal with these mammoth issues.The Assemblyman described his partyrsquos decision to re-enter the Executive as an act of ldquotrust and goodwill.He continued: ldquoWe all know the reasons why the last Executive failed and these have been well covered. While elements of this need to be addressed, which we wait for patiently, the SDLP team is firmly rooted in looking forward to a brighter future for all our people.ldquoWe now have our new Minister for Infrastructure in place in our deputy leader Nichola Mallon. Like all constituencies, South Down will benefit greatly from having as hard a working, fresh thinking and energetic a Minister in place as Nichola. The Infrastructure Ministry is also essential to our shared future.Mr McGrath said the SDLP had always been committed to ldquouniting peoplersquos hearts and minds first, suggesting that in Ms Mallon, his party had a minister in place who was ldquorooted in this and will now unite and connect the physical landscape of the north and the wider island of Ireland.The MLA declared: ldquoThese are exciting times and I look forward to meeting all of our new ministers and addressing the needs of the people in South Down, such as the protection of local and rural healthcare centres and rural schools etc. While these times are exciting, they are also faced with very serious pragmatism.ldquoPeople have been crying out for MLAs to get back to work as fully as possible. The SDLP has been fighting for this for three years and we can finally do it. Now, however, as we enter this new decade, is the time for delivery..prettyPhoto

title: O’Toole MLA in South Belfast
story: A FORMER Downpatrick man has been selected as the SDLPrsquos Assembly member for South Belfast.Matthew OrsquoToole mdash who was educated at St Patrickrsquos Grammar School and is a former Downing Street and Treasury adviser mdash replaces Claire Hanna following her election to Westminster last month.Mr OrsquoToole, who is the nephew of former Foyle MP and SDLP leader Mark Durkan, has a background in economic policy and communications.He says he is delighted to be asked to serve the people of South Belfast at what he described as ldquothis critical moment.ldquoThe absence of power-sharing has put immense pressure on public services, especially the health service, which is felt acutely in places like South Belfast, he said.Mr OrsquoToole, who left the British government in September  and works for communications consultancy Powerscourt, as well as contributing regular journalism on UK and Irish politics, said Brexit had made Northern Ireland ldquoimmensely vulnerable andwas damaging to community relations.He said the election to Westminster of ldquoprogressive, Remain voices like Ms Hanna and SDLP leader Colum Eastwood was good news and pledged to defend Northern Ireland from the effects of Brexit.ldquoI am humbled to be asked to serve a constituency that is Northern Irelandrsquos most erse and open, continued Mr OrsquoToole.ldquoI believe deeply in building in a shared society and South Belfast is an example of how a erse community can live and work together, I am proud to be their representative.Mr Eastwood said he was delighted that the party has announced that someone of Matthewrsquos calibre is stepping forward to join the SDLP Assembly team and represent the people of South Belfast.ldquoWith a strong background in economic policy, having worked across government and the private sector, Matthew brings an immense amount of experience that will be critical to our efforts to rebalance Northern Irelandrsquos economy, attract new jobs and defend people here from the impact of Brexit, said the SDLP leader.He added: ldquoI look forward to working with him at a critical time for politics in the north.Ms Hanna said her successor will make an ldquooutstanding Assembly member..prettyPhoto

title: Roads closed after gales uproot trees
story: STORM Brendan unleashed his fury across the district on Monday.Fallen trees forced the closure of roads mdash several of which still remained impassable or partially closed yesterday morning mdash while a small number of homes were left without electricity in the wake of the raging storm.Coastal roads in Newcastle, Strangford and Portaferry were buffeted with high waves, making driving hazardous for motorists, as storm gales reached speeds of up to mph.The Met Office had issued a yellow storm warning to hit Co Down. However, the district felt the brunt of the storm from early morning to late afternoon, making the daily commute to and from work and school dficult for many travellers.Early on Monday, Newry, Mourne and Down Council closed Delamont Country Park in Killyleagh ldquoas a precautionary measure along with several other of its parks in South Down. Castlewellan mountain bike trail was also closed.The Strangford to Portaferry ferry service was temporarily halted due to the gales. The landing area and the approach road to the ferry in Strangford was at one point swamped with water several feet deep.Police closed South Promenade in Newcastle in both directions due to the adverse weather conditions and advised motorists to seek alternative routes.There were also unconfirmed local reports that a boat sank in Newcastle harbour due to the ferocity of the winds and waves.The Killough Road in Downpatrick was closed until late yesterday afternoon.Also in Downpatrick, the Killyleagh Road was closed at the junction with the Strangford Road. One lane was reopened later.The fallen tree also impacted on NIE power lines, causing a loss of supply. The road was not completely open for travel until yesterday.The Old Belfast Road in Downpatrick was closed in both directions after a tree fell on the road between Quoile Bridge and the war memorial.There were also reports of road closures at Ballyknockan Road, Saintfield Ballagh Road, Newcastle and Manse Road, Carryduff Rubane Road Kircubbin and Moneyreagh Road, Ballygowan.An electricity cable came down on the Moneyscalp Road, Bryansford.Trees or branches which fell on to roads and caused issues for motorists were reported at the Buckrsquos Head, Annadoran Road area outside Downpatrick Church Road, Kilmore Saul Brae and Sievegrange Road, Downpatrick and Drumgavlin Road, near Ballynahinch.There were also reports of electricity supply being cut off in parts of the Castlewellan area..prettyPhoto

title: Shimna aces in spotlight
story: THERE were five star performances from both Shimna Stars male and female squads at Antrim Forum when they picked bonus points from round two of the Ulster Basketball League.The ladies team opened the day in Division  with a magnicent - win over Monaghan Kats. Demonstrating all their skills and movement, they overwhelmed the opposition and ended up deserved winners, thus setting up an interesting encounter with former team-mates, Antrim Borough SOC.With several players suffering from the earlier game and the loss of Tori to illness, the team were unlucky against the more experienced and stronger Antrim players and fell to - loss.The overall performance was magnicent and bodes well for the next round of games in March.Joint players of the day were Megan and Rachel who displayed great courage and spirit in both games.Ladies squad: Tori Campbell, Emma Clendinning, Michelle Coyne, Michelle Crawford, Orla McKervey, Rachel Breen, Megan RooneyThe male squad shook off the Christmas excesses with two terric displays against Coleraine Cougars SOC and Monaghan Shooters SOC.The game against the Coleraine Cougars is one to look back on with pride for the display of courage, character and team play displayed by the squad.After taking an early lead over Cougars, things went astray in the second quarter when Cougars came back into the game and took a six point lead. With their backs to the wall, Shimna pulled out all the stops and showed tremendous teamwork to claw back the lead and run out winners by two points.Such was the intensity of this game, the spectators were on the edge of their seats as the game swayed one way and then the other. Congratulations to both teams for a sporting game.Shimna Stars  Coleraine Cougars .The eagerly awaited rematch against Monaghan Shooters did not fully materialise as Shimna quickly got into their stride and outplayed Monaghan in every department.Superb outside shooting by Niall Campbell and excellent support play by Kris Nicholl earned them both team player of the day. This was truly a squad performance and every member played a signicant part in these victories.With two wins and two bonus points gained the league table will now take on a dferent perspective when published. Final score: Shimna  Monaghan Shooters .Male squad: Sean Brannigan, Niall Campbell, CJ Hennessy, Liam Hennessy, Patrick Hennessy, Rory McMullan, Niall Rogan, Aoacutedhan McConnell, Kris Nicholl, Jamie Dinsdale, Glenn McBride.Thanks to all who travelled and supported the teams. League day three is Saturday, March , at Foyle Arena.The committee, athletes and members of Shimna Stars Special Olympics Club extend condolences to the family of Ernie Jones who passed away recently. Ernie was a founder member of Shimna Stars SOC and is fondly remembered by all who came in contact with him during his tenure with the club. To our friend Carol and the entire family circle we offer our deepest sympathy..prettyPhoto

title: Slick Tyrone upset Down
story: DOWN salvaged some pride with an improved second half display at the Athletic Grounds in Armagh, but it was never going to be enough to overhaul a merciless Tyrone side.Mickey Hartersquos outfit, who had the wind in their backs in the first half, eased into a - to - lead by the break.Down were a dferent proposition and actually won the second  minutes - to -, but they paid a heavy price for a listless first half and some wayward shooting after the break.Tyrone raced into a - to - lead by the fth minute with a goal from Conall McCann in only the third minute, followed by points from Darren McCurry and a Ronan OrsquoNeill free.Down wasted a lot of possession in the opening exchanges, but still managed to get on the scoreboard with consecutive points from the hard-working Sean Dornan and Conor Poland.Tyrone, who defended in numbers and then hit on the break, set about dragging Down all over the place and scores from McCurry, McCann , Ronan OrsquoNeill and Frank Burns had the Red Hands - to - to the good by the rd minute.Pat Havern managed to reduce the leeway with a converted free for Down, but this was immediately cancelled out by a m free from McCurry.Poland, Downrsquos best player in the first half, lofted over another good score to leave seven points in it, but Tyrone finished the first half in a blaze of glory and unanswered points from Ben McDonnell and three from the immaculate McCurry had Hartersquos warriors - to - in front at the short whistle.Down were much more positive and direct at the start of the second half and points from Donal OrsquoHare, Pat Havern and Poland gave them some respite before that man McCurry pointed Tyrone into a - to - lead after  minutes.Paddy Tallyrsquos charges then wasted a few good scoring opportunities before Darren OrsquoHagan, with a point, Cory Quinn, with a goal and Ross McGarry, with a point, had Down only four points in arrears by the nd minute.However, their unlikely fightback hit the skid pans when Jonny Flynn was sin-binned after picking up a black card and with him went any hopes Down had of getting back on level terms.Tyrone responded with a rsquo from Brendan Gallen and a goal and a point from Ronan McHugh before Ronan McNamee completed their scoring. Liam Kerr added a late point for Down, but they were well beaten by this stage.Tyrone: B Gallen , HP McGeary, R McNamee , N Kelly, C McLaughlin, A McCrory, C Grimes, B McDonnell , F Burns , N Sludden, K Coney, D McCurry , K McGeary, C McCann , R OrsquoNeill . Subs: T McCann for Sludden, R McHughfor K McGeary, M Cassidy for HP McGeary, M OrsquoNeill for McLaughlin.Down: J OrsquoHare, G Collins, K McKernan, R McAleenan, P Laverty, D OrsquoHagan , R Carr, L Middleton, J Flynn, C Poland , C Quinn , B OrsquoHagan, C Harney, S Dornan , P Havern . Subs: L Kerrfor Middleton, D OrsquoHarefor Harney, D Guinness for Carr, R McGarryfor Havern, B Gallen for B OrsquoHagan.Tyrone -Down -McKENNA CUP SEMI-FINAL.prettyPhoto

title: Streets left in darkness
story: WHILE the lights are back on at Stormont they are continuing to go out across the district at an alarming rate mdash and with little prospect of them being repaired any time soon.The Down Recorder can reveal this week that almost  street lights are currently not working in East Down, plunging many areas into darkness and the Department for Infrastructure confirming that due to budgetary pressures, it is only able to provide a limited repair service.Province-wide, , street lights are currently not working with the government department having only eight engineers at its disposal to repair all of them.Downpatrick tops the league table for broken street lights in East Down with  in need of repair, with Newcastle sitting in second place. Across the resort,  street lights are not working.The figures are available on the NI Direct website under the reporting fault problems menu with other districthot-spots including Ballynahinch where  street lights are currently out of order.Elsewhere,  faults have been reported in Killyleagh, with  brought to the government departmentrsquos attention in Castlewellan and Crossgar. In Saintfield,  faults have been reported.In Ballygowan,  street lights are currently out of order with  and  faults reported in Ardglass and Killough respectively.Sixteen street lights are out of order in Dundrum with  faults reported in Drumaness. The figures for the Spa and Clough are  and nine respectively.Last month, the Department for Infrastructure confirmed that its current budget for street lighting repairs was approximately poundm, explaining that the figure was much lower than the pound.m needed to provide a full street lighting repair service.It also revealed that repairs are now generally limited to those that can be carried out by the departmentrsquos internal street lighting workforce which only consists of five full and three part time electricians.Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran described the number of reported street light faults across large parts of East Down as ldquoalarming and hopes that the money to expedite much-needed repairs will be earmarked by the new Stormont Executive.He said broken street lights in many areas represent a health and safety issue, explaining that an examination of every town and village across the district will reveal a signicant number of faults.Cllr Curran described faulty street lights as a ldquohot topic with politicians being contacted about the issue on all almost daily basis. He said the legacy of underfunding the roads department has experienced is now clear for all to see.The politician said many will be concerned that the Department for Infrastructure does not have the money it requires to carry out much-needed repairs.ldquoWhile I understand the decision to prioritise emergency repairs, there is no doubt that the alarming figure of almost  faulty street lights across East Down is simply going to increase. Clearly the issue is going to get a lot worse before it gets better, he said.ldquoStreet lights which are not working in areas where elderly people and indeed young families live poses a major problem. A fully working street lighting system provides residents with a sense of security and helps deter would-be criminals.Cllr Curran said that while the new Stormont Executive will inevitably face calls for investment in many key areas including health and education, the Department of Infrastructure also required an injection of funding.He added: ldquoWhile the focus for some will be on major new roads schemes which is understandable, it is clear that the creaking infrastructure the government department is responsible for, including street lighting, requires major cash injection.ldquoThe street lighting issues requires immediate attention. We are still in the grip of winter and several months away from the clearer evenings. Now that we have a local minister in place, I hope to meet her on this issue and other matters of local importance.A spokeswoman for the Department for Infrastructure said that in common with many other parts of the public service, the Department continued to face budget challenges and resources were currently not available to provide for a full street lighting repair service.She added: ldquoDue to this restricted service, outages are taking longer than usual to be repaired. However, priority will be given to hazardous electrical defects and group outages..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes to lawyer who was ‘a real gentleman’
story: TRIBUTES have been paid to a lawyer who died last week.Mr Paul McAlinden, who was a barrister, died peacefully in Belfast City Hospital last Wednesday. He had celebrated his th birthday on Boxing Day.At Downpatrick Court last Thursday, District Judge Amanda Brady led the tributes to Mr McAlinden.She described him as ldquoa real gentleman who earnestly tried to do his best for his clients.She said Mr McAlinden was always very pleasant and that she had never heard him complain.ldquoI was always impressed by his dignity and the courage he displayed during the last several months as he battled through his illness, she remarked.ldquoJudge Brady said Mr McAlindenrsquos motivation was his family and that he was devoted to his we, Fiona, and daughter Eileen.She added: ldquoEven though we knew he was sick, the news of his passing still comes as a shock. Irsquom still in disbelief and half expecting him to walk in to the court room.Mr McAlinden worked closely with Downpatrick solicitor Joe Mullholland for many years.Mr Mulholland, who was visibly emotional, said he had lost a dear friend and colleague.Mr Mulhollandrsquos practice colleague, Mr Chris Logue, described Mr McAlinden as being ldquopart of the furniture at the firm and said he will be ldquosorely missed as his team were ldquoheavily reliant upon him.A prosecution lawyer described Mr McAlinden as an ldquoabsolute gentleman and remarked: ldquoAlthough we had many heated exchanges I never heard Paul raise his voice. He was very much a family man. We could all see how ill he was, but the news of his passing still comes as a shock.Mr McAlinden was buried on Saturday following Requiem Mass in The Good Shepherd Church, Ormeau Road, Belfast..prettyPhoto

title: four people stand trial blackmail charge
story: Three men and a woman are to stand trial on charges related to the alleged blackmail of a male, who it is claimed paid out in excess of pound,.Paul Arthur Mayefrom Sallys Wood, Irvinestown is accused of demanding cash from the injured party with menaces on four occasions, the first of which was under the guise of payment to ldquorelease a lorry held at docks.He is also accused along with Patrick Thomas McDonaghof Tummery Road, Irvinestown of fraud by  representation, by telling the injured party pound, already paid out would be edhe in turn paid them pound, and doing so with menaces.The other defendants are Lisnaskea couple Christopher Francis McGovernand Sandra Morrisonfrom of Trasna Way are jointly charged with demanding pound from the injured party with menaces.Overall it is claimed the combined incidents occurred on ious dates between September  and January .While Fermanagh Magistrates Court was previously advised the case would be moving to trial, lawyers for the accused announced their intention to challenge some of the prosecution evidence.The committal hearing took the form of a preliminary investigation in which the injured party and two police officers were cross-exanimated on aspects of their evidence.Due to the nature of these hearings, the content cannot be published at this time.However, after this concluded, barristers for all four defendants contended on the basis of what was disclosed, their respective clients should not be ed for trial.But District Judge Steven Keown rejected their argument and held the prosecution case ldquohad not fallen short. He ruled there is satisfied there is a case to answer against all defendants, and any evidence which was disputed is a matter for the crown court.The committal procedure went ahead during which the defendants chose not to call witnesses or give evidence on their own behalf.Judge Keown remanded them on existing bail to appear before Dungannon Crown Court for formal arraignment next month.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: unions suspend strike action consider offer
story: Newly appointed Chair of the Health Committee, Sinn Feacuteins Colm Gildernew MLA, has welcomed todayrsquos announcement by health unions that they will suspending their industrial action.Speaking following the announcement, Colm Gildernew said: ldquoI welcome the decision by health unions to suspend planned health strikes and industrial action.Mr. Gildernew said there must be an inclusive approach to drafting the safe staffing plan which recognises and includes the important contribution of health unions and workers."I commend the fortitude of the health workers and their representatives during the industrial action and I welcome their decision to suspend the strike having secured pay parity and a commitment to safe staffing levels.ldquoThe workers were left no other option and took the decision to strike in the best interests of staff and patients alike.ldquoIt is vitally important that moving forward both the British and Irish Governments deliver on their financial commitments in the lsquoNew Decade, New Approachrsquo deal to allow for the proper resourcing of the health and social care service, education and other public services.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health.
